ARTICLE 15
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
02-15-01: Commission Information
02-15-03: Powers And Duties
02-15-05: Appeals To Council
02-15-07: Reference To Planning And/Or Zoning Commission
02-15-01: COMMISSION INFORMATION:
   (1)   Commission Created: There is hereby created a commission to be known
and designated as the planning and zoning commission. Said planning and zoning
commission is hereby created pursuant to section 67-6504 Idaho Code which may
act with the full authority of the governing board, excluding the authority to
adopt ordinances or to finally approve land subdivisions.
   (2)   Membership: The planning and zoning commission shall consist of not
less than three (3) nor more than seven (7) voting members, all appointed by
the mayor and confirmed by majority vote of the city council. An appointed
member of the commission must have resided in the city for at least two (2)
years prior to appointment and must remain a resident of the city during
service on the commission. For purposes of determining whether a person meets
the two (2) year residency requirements for service as a member of the planning
and zoning commission, the boundaries for the city in existence at the date of
appointment shall be considered as having existed, unchanged, for the two (2)
years preceding the date of appointment. The term of office for members shall
not be less than three (3) years, nor more than six (6) years. No person shall
serve more than two (2) full consecutive terms without specific concurrence by
two-thirds (2/3) of the council adopted by motion and recorded in the minutes.
Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of terms shall be
filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members may be removed
for cause by a majority vote of the city council. Members shall be selected
without respect to political affiliation and may receive mileage and per diem
compensation as provided by the city council.
   (3)   Organization: The commission shall elect a chairperson and create and
fill any other office it may deem necessary. The commission may establish
subcommittees, advisory committees or neighborhood groups to advise and assist
in carrying out responsibility under this article and provision of the Idaho
Code. The commission may appoint nonvoting, ex officio advisors as may be
deemed necessary.
   (4)   Rules, Records And Meetings: Written organization papers or bylaws
consistent with this article, Idaho Code, and other laws of the state for the
transaction of business of the commission shall be adopted. A record of
meetings, hearings, resolutions, studies, findings, permits and actions taken
shall be maintained. All meetings and records shall be open to the public. At
least one (1) regular meeting shall be held each month for not less than nine
(9) months in a year. A majority of currently appointed voting members of the
commission shall constitute a quorum.
   (5)   Expenditures And Staff: With approval of the city council through the
legally required budgetary process, the commission may receive and expend
funds, goods, and services from the federal government or agencies and
instrumentalities of state or local government or from civic and private
sources and may contract with these entities and provide information and
reports as necessary to secure aid. Expenditures by the commission shall be
within the amounts appropriated by the city council. Within such limits, any
commission is authorized to hire or contract with employees and technical
advisors, including, but not limited to, planners, engineers, architects and
legal assistants. (Ord. 1455, 2-7-1978; Ord. 1867, 9-4-1990; Ord. 2023, 2-22-
1994; Ord. 2776, 12-15-2008; Ord. 3470, 12-20-2022)
02-15-03: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   The Planning Process: As part of the planning process, the commission
shall provide for citizen meetings, hearings, surveys, or other methods to
obtain advice on the planning process, plan, and implementation. The commission
may also conduct informational meetings and consult with the public officials
and agencies, public utility companies, and civic, educational, professional,
or other organization. As part of the planning process, the commission shall
endeavor to promote a public interest in and understanding of the commission's
activities.
The commission may, at any time, make recommendations to the city council
concerning the plan, planning process, or implementation of the plan.
   (2)   Entry Powers: With the consent of the owner, the commission and its
members, officers and employees, in the performance of their functions, may
enter upon any land and make examination and surveys and place and maintain
necessary monuments and marks thereon.
   (3)   Judicial Process: The commission shall have the right to seek judicial
process, as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill its functions.
   (4)   Additional Duties As Assigned: The commission may perform such
additional duties as may be assigned by the city council. (Ord. 1376, 4-20-
1976)
02-15-05: APPEALS TO COUNCIL:
   The city council shall hear all appeals from a decision of the planning and
zoning commission concerning special use permits and variances and shall have
the power to permit special exceptions to the terms of the zoning regulations.
The council may uphold, reverse, or modify the action of the commission. All
decisions of the council to uphold, reverse or modify a decision of the
planning and zoning commission concerning special use permits and variances
shall be by a majority vote of the presiding council members. It is not
necessary for all six (6) council members to be in attendance at the council
meeting when an appeal is presented. In the event of a tie vote, the mayor
elect to vote in order to break a tie. (Ord. 1494, 6-20-1978; Ord. 2030, 6-20-
1994)
02-15-07: REFERENCE TO PLANNING AND/OR ZONING COMMISSION:
   All reference to planning and/or zoning commissions contained in this code
shall be interpreted to refer to the planning and zoning commission herein
created. (Ord. 2852, 12-20-2010)
ARTICLE 17
CALDWELL HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
02-17-01: Purpose
02-17-02: Definitions
02-17-03: Historic Preservation Commission
02-17-04: Procedures; Rules; Meetings; Officers
02-17-05: Powers And Duties Of Commission
02-17-06: Funding
02-17-07: Designation Of Local Historical Districts
02-17-08: Designation Of Historic Landmarks
02-17-09: Certificate Of Appropriateness Required
02-17-10: Application Requirements; Notice; Action; Appeal For Commission And
Staff Level Applications
02-17-11: Findings For Granting A Certificate Of Appropriateness
02-17-11-01: Alterations; Findings
02-17-11-02: Demolition Or Relocation; Findings
02-17-11-03: Change In Zoning Classification Or Change In Use; Findings
02-17-11-04: New Construction; Findings
02-17-12: Procedure For Demolition Or Change In Use Of Historic Landmark
02-17-13: Ordinary Repairs; Public Safety
02-17-14: Acquisition Of Property
02-17-15: Acquisition Of Historic Easements
02-17-16: Exemption From Fire Or Building Codes
02-17-17: Penalties; Remedies
02-17-01: PURPOSE:
   (1)   The purpose of this article is to promote the educational, cultural,
and economic welfare of the city by engaging in a comprehensive program of
historic preservation to promote, preserve, and protect historic buildings,
structures, sites, and monuments which serve as visible reminders of the
historical, archeological, architectural, educational, and cultural heritage of
the city.
   (2)   It is the further purpose of this article to allow for the social and
historical advantages of the city to promote the use and conservation of such
property; to stabilize and improve property values in local historic districts;
to promote the creation of local historic districts; and to encourage new
buildings and developments that will be harmonious with the existing
historical, archeological, and architectural structures, sites, and monuments.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-02: DEFINITIONS:
   For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words
shall have the meanings given herein:
   ACCESSORY BUILDING OR STRUCTURE: See section
10-03-11 of this code.
   ACQUISITION: The act or process of acquiring fee title or interest other
than fee title of real property (including acquisition of development rights or
remainder interest).
   ADDITION: Any construction that increases the size of an existing building
or structure in terms of site coverage, height, length, width or gross floor
area, including an additional floor.
   ALTERATIONS: Any act or process that changes one or more exterior features
of a building or site or any feature or object on a site.
   BUILDING (For Purposes Of Designation): A resource created principally to
shelter any form of human activity.
   CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS: The document issued by the Caldwell historic
preservation commission before any buildings, structures or accessory
buildings/structures are erected, altered, restored, moved or demolished within
a local historic district; before any alterations are made to the exterior of
sites or existing structures within a local historic district; before any
changes of use, zoning changes, home occupation permits, special use permits
and/or temporary use permits are allowed within a local historic district.
   CHARACTER DEFINING FACADE: Any elevation that contains features that helps
to define a structure's significance.
   COMMISSION: Caldwell historic preservation commission.
   CONTRIBUTING: A contributing building, site, structure, or object that adds
to the historic architectural qualities, historic associations, or
archeological values for which a property is significant because: a) it was
present during the period of significance, and possesses historic integrity
reflecting its character at that time or is capable of yielding important
information about the period, or b) it individually meets the national register
eligibility criteria. For inventory purposes, "primary" shall be used
synonymously with "contributing".
   COUNCIL: The Caldwell city council.
   DEMOLITION: Any act or process that permanently, substantially destroys, or
razes any building, site, structure, or object in whole or in part.
   DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT: Any act or omission that destroys or contributes to
the destruction of a building.
   EXTERIOR FEATURE: The architecture, size, location, type, style, kind,
texture, design, general arrangement and/or material of a building, site,
structure or object including, but not limited to, windows, doors, exterior
light fixtures, roofs, signs, appurtenant fixtures, and fencing, all as visible
from public right of way.
   HISTORIC EASEMENT: Any easement, restriction, covenant, or condition running
with the land designed and designated to preserve, maintain, and enhance all or
part of the existing places of historical, architectural, archeological,
educational, or cultural significance.
   HISTORIC LANDMARK: A district, site, building, structure, or object that
possesses exceptional significance in history, architecture, engineering,
archeology, or culture at the national, state, or local level and has been
designated as a historic landmark through the public hearing process outlined
herein and subsequent local ordinance.
   HISTORIC PRESERVATION: The research, protection, restoration, and
rehabilitation of buildings, sites, structures, objects, or districts
significant in the history, architecture, archeology or culture of the state,
its communities or the nation.
   HISTORIC PROPERTY: Any building, structure, area, or site that is
significant in the history, architecture, archeology, or culture of this state,
its communities, or the nation. A property can be an individual site or a
district consisting of multiple buildings, sites, structures, or objects.
   IMPROVEMENT: A valuable addition made to the property (usually real estate)
or amelioration in its condition, amounting to more than mere repairs or
replacement, costing labor or capital, and intended to enhance its value,
beauty, or utility or to adapt it for new or further purposes.
   INTEGRITY: The ability of a property to convey its significance; includes
the concepts of location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, feeling, and
association.
   LOCAL HISTORIC DISTRICT: Any area designated as such by ordinance which
includes or encompasses such historic buildings, sites, structures, or objects
as the commission may determine to be appropriate for historic preservation.
Such local district or districts need not be a single enclosed area nor do the
areas or sites have to be contiguous to constitute a district. A district may
include contributing, noncontributing, or undeveloped properties.
   LOCAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION PLAN: The organization into a logical sequence
of preservation information pertaining to identification, evaluation,
registration, and treatment of historic properties, and setting priorities for
accomplishing preservation activities, resulting in a written document.
   NATIONAL REGISTER: The national register of historic places. A list
established by the national historic preservation act of 1966 (as amended) and
codified in 36 CFR 60 (as amended) of buildings, sites, structures, objects,
and districts having local, state or national historical, architectural or
cultural significance and considered worthy of preservation.
   NATIONAL REGISTER CRITERIA: The established criteria for evaluating the
eligibility of properties for inclusion in the national register of historic
places. For further information on the criteria refer to the national park
service website, national register of historic places (http://www.cr.nps.gov/
nr).
   NEW CONSTRUCTION: Construction or installation of an entire structure,
whether primary, secondary or accessory.
   NONCONTRIBUTING: A building, site, structure, or object within a district
may be noncontributing because: a) it was not present during the period of
significance; b) due to alterations, disturbances, additions, or other changes,
it no longer possesses historic integrity reflecting its character at that time
or is incapable of yielding important information about the period; or c) it
does not individually meet the national register eligibility criteria. A
noncontributing building, site, structure, or object that is within a historic
district remains subject to this article. For inventory purposes, "secondary"
shall be used synonymously with "noncontributing". This classification has been
designated through a survey and a formal hearing process.
   OBJECT (For Purposes Of Designation): A construction primarily artistic in
nature or relatively small in scale and simply constructed, such as a statue or
milepost.
   PERIOD OF SIGNIFICANCE: The length of time when a property was associated
with important events, activities, or persons, or attained the characteristics
which qualify it for national register listing. Period of significance usually
begins with the date when significant activities or events began giving the
property its historic significance; this is often a date of construction.
   PERSON: An individual, firm, corporation, association, municipal
corporation, or any other governmental or quasi-governmental agency, or group
or combination thereof acting as a unit, except that nothing in this chapter
shall be construed to allow the designation, regulation, conditioning,
restriction, or acquisition of historic buildings, structures, sites or areas,
or other properties or facilities owned by the state or any of its political
subdivisions, agencies or instrumentalities.
   PERSON IN CHARGE: The person or persons possessed of the freehold, or a
mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor,
trustee, lessee, agent or any person directly or indirectly in control of a
historic property.
   PLANNING DIRECTOR: The planning and zoning director of the city of Caldwell
charged with the administration of the city's planning and zoning documents,
including those pertaining to historic preservation. This definition includes
the planning director's designated representative(s), also referred to in this
article as planning staff.
   PRESERVATION: The act or process of applying measures necessary to sustain
the existing form, integrity, and materials of a historic property. Work,
including preliminary measures to protect and stabilize the property, generally
focuses upon the ongoing maintenance and repair of historic materials and
features rather than extensive replacement and new construction. New exterior
additions are not within the scope of this treatment; however, the limited and
sensitive upgrading of mechanical, electrical and plumbing systems and other
code required work to make properties functional is appropriate within a
preservation project. Exterior additions should be sympathetic to the
significant elements of the historic property.
   PRIMARY FACADE: The elevation that most characterizes a structure's
significance; usually the front elevation.
   PROPERTY: Land and that which is erected or affixed to the land. Real
property extends to rights issuing out of, annexed to and exercisable within or
about land.
   PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY: A portion of land either dedicated or reserved for
public use which normally includes alleys, streets, sidewalks, utilities, or
other service functions. For purposes of this article, alleys shall not be
included as part of public right of way.
   RECONSTRUCTION: The act or process of depicting, by means of new
construction, the form, features, and detailing of a nonsurviving building,
site, structure, or object for the purpose of replicating its appearance at a
specific period of time and in its historic location.
   REHABILITATION: The act or process of making possible a compatible use for a
property through repair, alterations, and additions while preserving those
portions of features which convey its historical, cultural, or architectural
values.
   RESTORATION: The act or process of accurately depicting the forms, features,
and character of a property as it appeared at a particular period of time by
means of the removal of features from other periods in its history and
reconstruction of missing features from the restoration period. The limited and
sensitive upgrading of mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems and other
code required work to make properties functional is appropriate within a
restoration project.
   SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR'S STANDARDS FOR REHABILITATION: Standards that
were written pursuant to federal law to ensure that work on historic buildings
is done in such a manner which preserves the historical integrity of the
building. For further information refer to the "Secretary Of The Interior's
Standards For The Treatment Of Historic Properties With Guidelines For
Preserving, Rehabilitating, Restoring And Reconstructing Historic Buildings".
   SITE (For Purposes Of Designation): Location of a significant event, a
prehistoric or historic occupation or activity, or a building or structure,
whether standing, ruined or vanished, where the location itself possesses
historic, cultural or archeological value regardless of the value of any
existing structures.
   SITE IMPROVEMENTS: A modification to the grounds of a property not including
the buildings or accessory buildings. Such improvements may include, but are
not limited to: fences, walls, greenhouses, storage sheds, outdoor light
fixtures, patios, decks, porches, hot tubs, swimming pools, fountains,
barbecues, outdoor fireplaces, playground equipment, steps or pavement.
   STRUCTURE: (1) For Purposes Of Designation: A functional construction made
for purposes other than creating shelter, such as, but not limited to, a
bridge, canal, or dam.
(2) For All Other Purposes: Anything constructed or erected which requires
permanent location on the ground or is attached to something having location on
the ground. Structures may include, but are not limited to, buildings,
platforms, framework, antennas, and prefabricated sheds or other structures.
   SURVEY FORM: A form that catalogs the age, style, contributing or
noncontributing classification, address, location, photograph, date of
inventory, name of surveyor, building permit history and other relevant
information as may be required by the planning director or commission for a
building, site, structure, or object.
   TEMPORARY FEATURES: Items that are erected or displayed for a limited amount
of time, not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days at any one time unless
otherwise approved by the planning director, which may include, but are not
limited to: sidewalk cafe tables, fences, chairs, planters, umbrellas, and
bicycle racks.
   TEMPORARY STRUCTURES: A structure with or without a foundation that is
erected for a limited amount of time, not to exceed one hundred eighty (180)
days at any one time unless otherwise approved by the planning director, which
may include, but is not limited to, playhouses and play equipment, mobile
buildings and carport/canopy structures. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-03: HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION:
   (1)   There is hereby created and established a historic preservation
commission which shall consist of no less than five (5) but up to ten (10)
members who shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the
council. In addition, there shall be one nonvoting liaison member from the
council or city staff.
   (2)   Members of the commission shall be appointed with due regard to the
proper representation of such fields as history, architecture, urban planning,
education, archeology, and law. Appointed members of the commission shall live
or work in the city or in the city's impact area during the full term of
service.
   (3)   The members of the commission are eligible for reappointment without
regard to the number of terms having been previously served. If a vacancy
occurs, the mayor with the consent of the council shall appoint a member to
fill the unexpired term.
   (4)   The members of the commission shall serve without pay but shall be
reimbursed, with prior permission, by the city for necessary expenses incurred
in connection with their duties.
   (5)   A quorum shall consist of at least fifty percent (50%) or greater of
the current membership and shall not include the nonvoting liaison member from
council or city staff.
   (6)   The commission may employ such qualified staff personnel as it deems
necessary.
   (7)   Any member who is absent from four (4) regular meetings in a calendar
year will be notified by letter that the absence limit has been reached. If the
member is subsequently absent from a fifth regular meeting in that same
calendar year, the absence record shall be forwarded to the mayor for action.
Failure to meet attendance requirements for regular meetings shall be
sufficient grounds for removal from the commission by action of the city
council. Members may request a leave of absence for periods of two (2) months
to one year, and upon favorable recommendation by the commission and approval
of the city council, each leave may be obtained with no adverse impact upon the
member's absence record.
   (8)   All members of the commission shall attend at least one meeting or
training, per year, sponsored by any preservation organization or related
organization. Attendance at commission meetings does not count toward this
requirement. Failure to meet this requirement shall be sufficient grounds for
removal from the commission by action of the city council. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-
2012)   
02-17-04: PROCEDURES; RULES; MEETINGS; OFFICERS:
   (1)   Rules: The commission may establish any rules necessary for the
orderly conduct of its business, and all meetings of the commission shall be
open to the public.
   (2)   Record: The commission shall keep a record of its attendance,
resolutions, proceedings, and actions. The minutes of the preceding commission
meetings shall be approved by the commission before any further distribution of
such minutes is made. A copy of the minutes of each meeting shall be kept on
file at the planning and zoning department and city hall.
   (3)   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings shall be scheduled once a month
unless there are not any certificates of appropriateness to review or other
pertinent commission business to discuss.
   (4)   Special Meetings: A special meeting may be called by the chair of the
commission whenever he/she deems such meeting necessary. Such special meeting
shall be held at the time and place specified in the call for such a meeting
and each member of the commission shall be notified of the time and place of
special meetings.
   (5)   Quorum Present: In case there shall be no quorum present on the day
fixed for a regular or special meeting, the commission members present may
adjourn to a specified date and time until a quorum is obtained.
   (6)   Elect Officers: At the first meeting of the calendar year, the
appointed commissioners shall elect officers who shall be commission members
and who shall serve for terms of one year.
   (7)   Chair: The chair of the commission shall preside at all meetings of
the commission at which he/she is present. He/she shall conduct public hearings
and other public and official meetings held by the commission. The chair shall
exercise general guidance and supervision over business and operation of the
commission and shall present to the commission such matters as, in his/her
judgment, require the attention of the commission. The chair shall execute all
formal documents, including certificates of appropriateness, on behalf of the
commission and shall, at all times, represent the commission in the absence of
a duly appointed alternate. The chair of the commission shall vote on all
matters and shall have equal privileges as a commission member including the
right to surrender the chair for purposes of making motions or introducing
resolutions.
   (8)   Vice Chair: In the absence of the chair of the commission, the vice
chair of the commission, or in his/her absence, a commissioner elected by a
quorum of the commission shall accede to the duties and obligations of the
office of chair of the commission.
   (9)   Planning And Zoning Staff: Planning and zoning staff shall be
secretary/clerk for the commission and shall be responsible for swearing in
those who need to testify under oath, taking and keeping minutes and records
for all meetings and hearings, preparing and distributing agendas, keeping
records of properties within local historic districts, and all similar items.
   (10)   Committees: The chair of the commission shall appoint such committees
as the commission may direct. He/she may appoint such additional committees as
he/she deems necessary to accomplish the work of the commission.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012; amd. Ord. 3047, 3-21-2016; Ord. 3532, 9-5-2023; Ord.
3541, 10-17-2023; Ord. 3604, 6-18-2024; Ord. 3626, 8-19-2024)
02-17-05: POWERS AND DUTIES OF COMMISSION:
   (1)   The commission shall exercise to the fullest extent the authority
granted under title 67 (state government and state affairs), chapter 46
(preservation of historic sites) of the Idaho state code and shall be
authorized to:
      A.   Conduct surveys of local historic properties.
      B.   Acquire fee and lesser interests in historic properties, including
adjacent or associated lands, by purchase, bequest or donation, but shall not
be authorized to acquire historic properties by condemnation.
      C.   Preserve, restore, maintain, and operate historic properties under
the ownership or control of the commission.
      D.   Lease, sell, and otherwise transfer or dispose of historic
properties subject to rights of public access and other covenants and in a
manner that will preserve the property.
      E.   Contract, with the approval of council, with the state or federal
government, or any agency of either, or with any other organization.
      F.   Cooperate with the federal, state, and local governments in the
pursuit of the objectives of historic preservation.
      G.   Participate in the conduct of land use, urban renewal, and other
planning processes undertaken by the city.
      H.   Recommend ordinances and otherwise provide information for the
purposes of historic preservation to the council.
      I.   Promote and conduct an educational and interpretive program on
historic properties within the jurisdiction of the city.
      J.   Enter, solely in performance of its official duties and only at
reasonable times, upon private lands for examination or survey thereof.
However, no member, employee, or agent of the commission may enter any private
property, building, or structure without the express consent of the owner or
occupant thereof.
      K.   Prepare, adopt, maintain, and update a local historic preservation
plan for the city. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-06: FUNDING:
   (1)   For the purpose of providing funds for a historic preservation
commission, the council may:
      A.   Provide funds from current revenues;
      B.   Receive and expend monies from any other available source or
sources; or
      C.   Use any combination of subsections (1)A and (1)B of this section.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
   (2)   Any funds received by the historic preservation commission may be
accumulated from year to year and need not be expended during any one fiscal
year, provided that the maximum accumulation of funds received from ad valorem
taxes shall not exceed twice the amount of money authorized by the council in
the previous year pursuant to subsection (1) of this section. (Ord. 2923, 4-15-
2013)
02-17-07: DESIGNATION OF LOCAL HISTORICAL DISTRICTS:
   (1)   Establishment Of Districts: The city may establish by ordinance one or
more local historic districts within the area of its jurisdiction. No local
historic district or districts shall be designated until a minimum of one of
the following has been established: a) historical or cultural importance; b)
architectural importance; or c) archeological importance, as outlined below.
      A.   Criteria For Designation: The buildings, sites, structures, and
objects of a local historic district shall meet one of the following three (3)
criteria:
         1.   Historical Or Cultural Importance:
            (A)   Has significant character, interest or value, as part of the
development, heritage, or cultural characteristics of the city, state, or
nation; or is associated with the life of a person significant in the past; or
            (B)   Is the site of a historic event with a significant effect
upon society; or
            (C)   Exemplifies the cultural, political, economic, social,
educational, or historic heritage of the community; or
            (D)   By being part of or related to a street, square, park or
other distinctive area, should be developed or preserved according to a plan
based on historic, cultural, or architectural motif; or
            (E)   Owing to its unique location or singular physical
characteristic, represents an established and familiar visual feature of the
neighborhood, community, or city; or
         2.   Architectural Importance:
            (A)   Portrays the environment; or
            (B)   Embodies those distinguishing characteristics of an
architectural type or engineering specimen; or
            (C)   Is the work of a designer, architect, or craftsman whose
individual work has significantly influenced the development of the city,
state, or nation; or
            (D)   Contains elements of design, detail, materials or
craftsmanship which represent a significant innovation; or
         3.   Archeological Importance:
            (A)   Has yielded or may be likely to yield, information important
in prehistory or history; or
            (B)   Contains or is likely to contain physical remains, such as
relics, monuments, art or symbols, of past human life and activities.
   (2)   Commission Research And Report On Proposed District:
      A.   The commission, either by its own initiative or upon the request of
the council, or upon the request of one or more owners of property in the area
of a proposed local historic district, may recommend the designation of one or
more local historic districts.
      B.   Prior to recommending designation the commission shall make an
investigation of the historical, architectural, archeological, and cultural
significance of the buildings, structures, features, sites, or surroundings
included in any such proposed local historic district based on the relevant
criteria listed in subsection (1) of this section.
      C.   Thereafter, the commission shall prepare a report containing
recommendations concerning the area or areas to be included in the proposed
local historic district or districts.
   (3)   Transmittal Of Report To Planning And Zoning Commission:
      A.   Copies of the report shall be transmitted to the Caldwell planning
and zoning commission for review and recommendation through the public hearing
process as outlined in chapter 10 of this code. Not less than sixty (60) days
after the date of transmittal of such report to the planning and zoning
commission, the historic preservation commission shall hold a public hearing
regarding the proposed local historic district.
   (4)   Notice Requirements Of The Public Hearing For Historic Preservation
Commission:
      A.   Notice of the time, place, and purpose of such hearing shall be
given at least fifteen (15) calendar days prior to the hearing by one
publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city; and
      B.   Written notice of the hearing shall be given to the owners of all
properties, as well as occupants of the properties if different from the
owners, to be included in the local historic district or districts at least
fifteen (15) calendar days prior to the hearing.
   (5)   Final Report To City Council:
      A.   After conducting the public hearing, the commission may vote to
proceed with the proposed local historic district, and shall submit a final
report with its recommendations, as well as the recommendations of the planning
and zoning commission, and a draft ordinance to the city council.
   (6)   Public Hearing By City Council:
      A.   The city council shall act on the report and recommendation in
accordance with the public hearing provisions of chapter 10 of this code. Upon
approval by the council of the ordinance establishing the local historic
district, the zoning maps shall be changed to reflect the addition of the
applicable local historic district overlay zone.
   (7)   Notification Of District:
      A.   Upon adoption of the ordinance, the owners of each property within
the local historic district shall be given written notification of said
designation. Occupants of each property, if different from the owners, shall
also be given written notification. Written notifications shall be the
responsibility of the planning and zoning department.
      B.   The planning and zoning department shall also notify the following
city departments of such designation: fire department, building department,
engineering department, and mapping department.
      C.   One copy of the ordinance creating the local historic district shall
be filed in the office of the county recorder of Canyon County, Idaho, by the
city clerk.
   (8)   Record Of Local Historic Districts:
      A.   The planning and zoning department shall maintain a record of local
historic districts, and all properties within local historic districts.
      B.   All properties within a local historic district may be marked with a
suitable sign or marker on or near the property indicating that the property
has been so designated as part of a local historic district.
   (9)   Investigation Or Report Updates:
      A.   The physical changes in a local historic district that are approved
by a certificate of appropriateness shall be added to the record maintained by
the planning and zoning department as identified in subsection (8) of this
section. Updates to the record are not considered amendments to the local
historic district. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-08: DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC LANDMARKS:
Historic landmarks shall be designated by ordinance and in accordance with the
following requirements:
   (1)   The building, site, structure, or object proposed for such designation
may be so designated on the following criteria: historical, architectural,
archeological, and cultural significance; suitability for preservation or
restoration; educational value; cost of acquisition, restoration, maintenance,
operation, or repair; possibilities for adaptive or alternative use of the
property; appraised value; and the administrative and financial responsibility
of any person or organization willing to underwrite all or a portion of such
costs. In addition, it must meet the criteria established for inclusion in the
national register of historic places.
   (2)   The commission, either on its own initiative or upon the request of
the city council, or upon the request of owner of the property proposed to be
designated, may recommend the designation of a historic landmark. Prior to
recommending the designation, the commission shall conduct studies, research,
and investigations based on the relevant criteria listed in subsection (1) of
this section. Thereafter, the commission shall prepare a report containing
recommendations concerning the historic landmark proposed to be designated and
a draft of the designating ordinance to be presented to the city council for
consideration during a public hearing. The report of the commission shall
include comments regarding the suitability of the historic landmark for
preservation or restoration.
   (3)   For each designated historic landmark, the designating ordinance shall
require the waiting period prescribed by section
02-17-12 of this article to be observed prior to its demolition, material
alteration, remodeling or removal. The designating ordinance shall also provide
guidelines for a suitable sign or marker on or near the historic landmark
indicating that the property has been so designated.
      A.   For properties both designated as a historic landmark and located
within a local historic district, the portion of this article pertaining to the
districts, takes precedence over the waiting period for demolition, material
alteration, remodeling, or removal of the structure.
      B.   For state or federal properties which are designated as historic
landmarks, the designation is an honorary effort and the city acknowledges that
the repair, maintenance, demolition, or remodel of the structure is not within
its jurisdiction.
   (4)   The city council shall hold a public hearing on the designating
ordinance, after having given written notice to the owners and occupants of the
property and the publication of such notice in the time and manner required by
section
02-17-07 of this article.
   (5)   Following such public hearing, the council may act on the designating
ordinance.
   (6)   Upon passage of the designating ordinance, the owners and occupants of
each designated historic landmark shall be given written notification of said
designation by the council, and one copy of the designating ordinance shall be
filed in the office of the county recorder of Canyon County, Idaho, by the city
clerk.
   (7)   The city clerk shall give notice of such designation to the tax
assessor of Canyon County, Idaho. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-09: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS REQUIRED:
   (1)   Alterations And/Or New Construction In Local Historic Districts:
      A.   General Rules:
         1.   After the designation by ordinance of a local historic district,
no "exterior feature", as defined within this article, of any building, site,
structure or object, including all appurtenant features, nor aboveground
utility structure nor any type of outdoor advertising sign shall be erected,
altered, restored, moved, or demolished within such local historic district
until after an application for a certificate of appropriateness has been
submitted to the planning and zoning department and approved by the commission.
         2.   A certificate is required whether or not a building permit is
required, and a certificate of appropriateness must be granted in all cases
before an applicant can obtain any other permit.
         3.   As part of the application process for a certificate of
appropriateness, the planning staff shall confirm the contributing or
noncontributing classification of the property based upon the survey records.
         4.   The commission may delegate to the planning staff review of
certificates of appropriateness that are listed as "staff level" under the
certificate of appropriateness matrix adopted by the commission and that are in
compliance with the secretary of the interior's standards for rehabilitation
and guidelines for rehabilitating historic buildings and the Steunenberg
residential historic district design guidelines.
      B.   Exceptions: No certificate of appropriateness is required for the
following items:
         1.   Interior arrangement of any building or structure or any interior
features or fixtures;
         2.   Temporary structures and features that do not remain in existence
for a time period greater than a total of forty-five (45) days in any
consecutive twelve (12) month period.
         3.   A site or building improvement that does not require a
certificate in the certificate of appropriateness matrix as adopted by
resolution by the commission and on file in the planning and zoning department.
   (2)   Demolition Or Relocation In Local Historic Districts: After the
designation by ordinance of a local historic district, no building, site,
structure or object which is a part of such district shall be demolished or
moved until after an application for a certificate of appropriateness relating
to the demolition or moving of such building, site, structure or object has
been submitted to and approved by the commission through a public hearing. A
certificate of appropriateness will be required whether or not a building
permit is required and a certificate of appropriateness must be granted in all
cases before an applicant can obtain any other permit required for the
demolition or moving of any building, site, structure or object which is part
of a local historic district.
   (3)   Change In Zoning Classification And/Or Change In Use In Designated
Local Historic Districts: Any change in zoning classification as well as any
change in use, preliminary plat, special use, temporary use, and/or home
occupation within a local historic district shall first require approval and
issuance of a certificate of appropriateness before an applicant can apply for
or obtain any other permit or license that may be required. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-
2012)
02-17-10: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS; NOTICE; ACTION; APPEAL FOR COMMISSION AND
STAFF LEVEL APPLICATIONS:
   (1)   Application Requirements:
      A.   An application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be
submitted by the owner of the property, or by a representative of such person,
on a form obtained from the Planning and Zoning Department and containing such
information as required by the commission.
      B.   The applicant shall be solely responsible for submitting a complete
application in enough time to ensure all required notification deadlines, as
outlined in this article, are able to be met.
      C.   An application seeking demolition or relocation shall provide the
following:
         1.   A written statement as to why the building, site, structure, or
object should be demolished.
         2.   Photographs of the building, site, structure, or object to be
demolished, as well as of adjacent properties.
         3.   If applicants wish to be considered for the finding under
subsection
02-17-11-02(1)D of this article they shall provide the following additional
information:
            (A)   Two (2) written reports, prepared, stamped, and signed by
currently licensed Idaho design professionals appropriate to the nature of the
project, at least one of which shall be disinterested, stating the structural
soundness of the building or structure proposed for demolition and suitability
for reuse.
            (B)   An analysis of the cost to rehabilitate the existing
structure plus construct the additional square footage and other goals of the
application. These costs shall be completed to include the cost of demolishing
any existing structures and the equivalent new construction and shall be
completed, signed, and stamped by a currently licensed Idaho design/contract
professional appropriate to the nature of the project. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
   (2)   Public Meetings, Hearings, Notification, And Action For Commission
Level Applications:
      A.   Public Meetings; Notice: Prior to approval or denial of a
certificate of appropriateness for window, door, roofing, siding replacement,
and fencing, except for those certificate of appropriateness approved by staff
level, a public meeting shall be held, notice shall be posted on the premises
not less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the meeting.
      B.   Hearing; Notice: Prior to approval or denial of a certificate of
appropriateness for demolition, relocation, zone change, change of use,
additions, alterations or new construction a public hearing shall be held,
notice shall be posted on the premises not less than seven (7) calendar days
prior to the meeting and notice shall be mailed to the applicant, the property
owners and residents within three hundred feet (300') of the exterior boundary
of the parcel under consideration, and to any applicable registered
neighborhood associations a minimum of fifteen (15) days prior to said public
hearing.
      C.   Incomplete Application: In the event the commission receives an
application for review that the commission deems incomplete or needing
additional information, the request shall be continued to the next meeting.
      D.   Representative Must Be Present: The property owner(s) or property
owner's representative shall be present at the meeting for the commission to
take action on the application.
      E.   Agenda: The complete agenda for all meetings shall be posted on the
City's website and in the Development Services Building.
      F.   Action By The Commission:
         1.   Approvals: If the commission determines the proposed request is
appropriate, it shall approve such application with its reasons for the
decision and any applicable conditions of approval and shall issue to the
applicant a certificate of appropriateness.
         2.   Denials: If the commission determines that a certificate of
appropriateness should not be issued, it shall place upon its records the
reason for such determination and shall notify the applicant in writing of its
reasons and recommendations, if any, as to what actions could be taken in order
to obtain a certificate.
   (3)   Action And Notification For Staff Level Certificates:
      A.   Within a minimum of ten (10) business days after receipt of an
application, planning staff shall investigate the request and shall either
approve, modify, or deny such application.
      B.   Within five (5) business days of the decision, planning staff shall
notify, in writing, the applicant. Notification shall be deemed complete on the
date notice is provided to the applicant.
   (4)   Appeals:
      A.   Appeal Of Commission Level Decisions: Any applicant or property
owner or resident within three hundred feet (300') of the subject property
aggrieved by a determination of the commission may appeal to the Council within
fifteen (15) calendar days from the date the Certificate of Appropriateness is
approved or denied. The decision is deemed to have been made on the date the
commission signs the order of decision. An appeal from the Council may be taken
to a court of competent jurisdiction.
      B.   Appeal Of Staff Level Decisions: A decision of planning staff may be
appealed to the commission within fifteen (15) calendar days from the date the
Certificate of Appropriateness is approved or denied. The applicant may request
a waiver of the fifteen (15) day appeal period for staff level approvals if the
request is made in writing and accompanied by the signatures of all adjacent
property owners and residents indicating that they do not object to the waiver
request. Planning staff shall review all pertinent information and issue a
decision on the request. (Ord. 3126, 1-16-2018)
   (5)   Term Of Approval: The term of approval for a certificate of
appropriateness shall be twelve (12) months from the date of signature on the
certificate or may be extended through the issuance of a valid building permit.
The certificate of appropriateness is issued to the property owner and is valid
for both the property and whoever owns the property, within the applicable one
year time frame. If the property is sold within the one year time frame, the
certificate of appropriateness shall be transferred from the previous owner to
the new owner. Certificates of appropriateness shall not be transferred from
one property site to another property site but may be transferred between
property owners on and for the same property site. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-11: FINDINGS FOR GRANTING A CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
   (1)   The commission shall review application(s) with the findings outlined
below as pertaining to the request for a certificate of appropriateness. The
commission may attach conditions of approval to the application to ensure
compliance with the findings. Modifications to the application may be submitted
and will be considered at a staff level. In reviewing the modification,
planning staff will utilize the original findings under which the application
was reviewed to ensure the project still complies with the requirements for a
certificate of appropriateness. (Ord. 3126, 1-16-2018)

   (2)   The commission shall find that the design of the project is consistent
with the following plans and guidelines that apply to the property:
      A.   U.S. Secretary of the Interior's standards for rehabilitation and
guidelines for rehabilitating historic buildings.
      B.   Chapter 10 of this Code, as amended and adopted by City Council.
      C.   Steunenberg Residential Historic District design guidelines, as
amended and adopted (copies available in the Caldwell Planning and Zoning
Department).
      D.   City of Caldwell Comprehensive Plan, as amended and adopted by City
Council. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-11-01: ALTERATIONS; FINDINGS:
   (1)   The commission's decision in regard to certificates of appropriateness
for alterations shall be based on the following findings as applicable to that
property or request and as they relate to historic preservation:
      A.   That the request is consistent with the Steunenberg Residential
Historic District design guidelines.
      B.   That the request is consistent with the Secretary of the Interior's
standards for rehabilitation and guidelines for rehabilitating historic
buildings.
      C.   That the request supports the goals, policies, and recommendations
of the City of Caldwell's Comprehensive Plan and the plans referenced therein.
      D.   That based on the adopted design guidelines the request will not be
incongruous with the historical, architectural, archeological, educational, or
cultural aspects of the local district.
      E.   That the request complies with the dimensional standards and other
applicable requirements of chapter 10 of this code including, but not limited
to, setbacks, height restrictions and parking requirements, unless the
commission finds that modifying those standards is necessary to protect the
overall characteristics of the local district and to comply with the adopted
design guidelines. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-11-02: DEMOLITION OR RELOCATION; FINDINGS:
   (1)   In order for the commission to approve a demolition or relocation
request at least three (3) out of the following five (5) findings must be met:
      A.   That the building, site, structure, or object is not classified as
contributing within the local district as stated on the survey form on file in
the planning and zoning department.
      B.   That the building, site, structure, or object cannot reasonably meet
national, state, or local criteria for designation as a historic property.
      C.   That the demolition of the building, site, structure, or object
would not have an adverse impact on the character of the district and/or the
adjacent properties and/or would not put the district at risk of losing
historical status.
      D.   That the owner has reasonably demonstrated that rehabilitation of
the building, site, structure, or object would not be economically practical,
realistic, or viable based on review of the information required in subsection
02-17-10(1)C3 of this article.
      E.   That plans have been submitted to redevelop the property if the
demolition proceeds and such plans will have a positive effect on the district
and/or adjacent properties. The size, scale, use, materials, and/or overall
design of the project may be considered as qualities for producing a positive
effect. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-11-03: CHANGE IN ZONING CLASSIFICATION OR CHANGE IN USE; FINDINGS:
   (1)   The commission's decision in regard to certificates of appropriateness
for a change in zoning classification, change in use, home occupation permit,
special use permit, and/or temporary use permit shall be based on the following
findings:
      A.   That the request supports the city of Caldwell's comprehensive plan
goals, policies, and recommendations contained within section 11, special
sites/historic areas, of said plan.
      B.   That the request will be congruous with the historical,
architectural, archeological, educational, or cultural significance of the
local district.
      C.   There will be no significant effect on the exterior of the site.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-11-04: NEW CONSTRUCTION; FINDINGS:
   (1)   The following objectives and findings, in addition to those cited
under section
02-17-11-01 of this article, shall be considered where applicable to the
proposal:
      A.   Minimizes Traffic Impact: That the site design minimizes impact of
traffic on adjacent streets and that the pedestrian and bicyclist have been
provided for by requiring sidewalks, landscaping, and safe parking lot design
as appropriate.
      B.   Landscaping: That the proposed landscaping enhances the historic
district and neighborhood with attributes that include, but are not limited to,
protection of desirable existing trees, provision of street trees, and adequate
screening methods where needed to buffer adjacent uses and unsightly areas or
features.
Considerations relative to this subsection (1)B:
         1.   The location, height and materials of walls, fences, hedges, and
screening plantings to ensure harmony with adjacent developments;
         2.   The planting of street trees and the unnecessary destruction of
existing trees and landscape features;
         3.   The provision of plantings or other screening methods reasonably
required to conceal outdoor storage areas, trash receptacles, exposed machinery
installation, utility buildings and installations and similar accessory areas
or other unsightly developments.
      C.   On Site Grading And Drainage: That on site grading and drainage have
been designed so as to minimize off site impact and provide for erosion control
as required by the city of Caldwell.
      D.   Review Of Building Mass: That the mass of the building shall be
reviewed for its relationship to other buildings within the local historic
district.
      E.   Proportion Of Building Facades: The height to width relationship
shall be compatible and consistent with the predominant architectural character
of the local historic district.
      F.   Shadow Relief/Design Interest: The exterior of the building shall
provide shadow relief and design interest compatible with the architectural
character of the local historic district.
      G.   Appropriateness Of Materials: The appropriateness of materials shall
be reviewed as they relate to building mass, shadow relief, and compatibility
with other buildings within the local historic district.
      H.   Consistency Of Design: The commission shall find that the design of
the project is consistent with the plans and guidelines listed in section
 02-17-11 of this article. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-12: PROCEDURE FOR DEMOLITION OR CHANGE IN USE OF HISTORIC LANDMARK:
   (1)   A historic landmark so designated by ordinance, which is not part of a
local historic district, may be demolished, materially altered, remodeled,
relocated or put to a different use only after one hundred eighty (180) days'
written notice of the owner's proposed action has been given to the commission
in accordance with the following procedures:
      A.   During this period, the commission may negotiate with the owner and
with any other parties in an effort to find a means of preserving the property.
      B.   During this period, or at any time prior thereto following notice of
designation to the owner, and where such action is reasonably necessary or
appropriate for the continued preservation of the property, the commission may
enter into negotiations with the owner for the acquisition by gift, purchase,
or exchange of the property or any interest therein.
   (2)   The commission may reduce the waiting period required by this section
in any case where the owner would suffer extreme hardship, unless a reduction
in the required period was allowed. The commission shall have the discretionary
authority to waive all or any portion of the required waiting period, provided
that the alteration, remodeling, relocation or change of use is undertaken
subject to conditions agreed to by the commission ensuring the continued
maintenance of the historical, architectural, archeological or cultural
integrity and character of the property.
   (3)   At the end of the required waiting period, as reduced or waived if
such is the case, the designation of such historic landmark shall be rescinded
as necessary and a draft of a proposed ordinance removing such designation
shall be prepared and submitted to the council for approval. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-
2012)
02-17-13: ORDINARY REPAIRS; PUBLIC SAFETY:
   (1)   Nothing in this article shall be construed to prevent the ordinary
maintenance or repair of any exterior feature in a local historic district, or
of any historic landmark, which does not involve a change in design, material
or outer appearance thereof, nor to prevent the construction, reconstruction,
alteration, restoration or demolition of any such feature when the building
official shall certify such is required for the public safety because of an
unsafe or dangerous condition.
   (2)   Neither the owner nor the person in charge of a designated historic
landmark or property within a local historic district shall permit it to fall
into a state of disrepair which may result in the deterioration of any exterior
appurtenance or architectural feature so as to produce or tend to produce, in
the judgment of the commission, a detrimental effect upon its historic
character, including, but not limited to, the deterioration of exterior walls
or other vertical supports; the deterioration of the foundation; the
deterioration of exterior chimneys; the deterioration of roofs or other
horizontal members; the deterioration or removal of exterior finishes or
fenestration; the ineffective waterproofing of exterior walls, roofs and
foundations including broken windows or doors; and/or the deterioration of any
feature so as to create or permit the creation of any hazardous or unsafe
condition or conditions.
      A.   If the commission makes a preliminary determination that a property
is being demolished by neglect as described in this subsection (2), it shall
direct planning and zoning code enforcement to notify the owner(s) of the
property of this preliminary determination, stating the reasons therefor and
the actions necessary, and shall give the owner of record twenty- eight (28)
days from the date of mailing of such notice to submit a plan and a time frame
to correct the specific defects as determined by the commission. (Ord. 2905, 9-
4-2012)
02-17-14: ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY:
   (1)   All lands, buildings, structures, sites or areas acquired by funds
appropriated by the city shall be acquired in the name of the city unless
otherwise provided by the governing board. So long as owned by the city,
historic properties may be maintained by or under the supervision and control
of the city.
   (2)   Nothing in this article shall be construed to allow the designation,
regulation conditioning, restriction or acquisition of historic buildings,
structures, sites or areas, or other properties or facilities owned by the
state or any of its political subdivisions, agencies or instrumentalities.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-15: ACQUISITION OF HISTORIC EASEMENTS:
   (1)   The city may acquire, by purchase or donation, historic easements in
any area within the jurisdiction of the city wherever and to the extent the
council determines that the acquisition will be in the public interest.
   (2)   The council shall seek a recommendation from the commission regarding
the historic easement and proposed resolution. (Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-16: EXEMPTION FROM FIRE OR BUILDING CODES:
   The council, in order to promote the preservation and restoration of any
historic landmark/property, or property within a local historic district may,
upon recommendation of the commission, exempt a historic landmark or property
within a local historic district from the application of the city fire or
building codes upon compliance with the criteria for exemption set forth in
said codes, and provided the city has adopted such codes, and upon a finding
that nonexemption would prevent or seriously hinder the preservation or
restoration of said historic landmark or property in a local historic district.
(Ord. 2905, 9-4-2012)
02-17-17: PENALTIES; REMEDIES:
   (1)   Any person or corporation, whether owner, lessee, principal agent,
employee or otherwise, violating any portion of this article or permitting any
such violation or failing to comply with any of the requirements contained
within this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not
exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00). Each day that a violation continues
to exist may constitute a separate offense. The availability of criminal
prosecution of violators of this article shall in no way limit the other
remedies that may be available to the city to enforce the provisions of this
article, whether in law or in equity, including injunctive relief. (Ord. 2905,
9-4-2012)
ARTICLE 19
CALDWELL TRAFFIC COMMISSION
SECTION:
02-19-01: Commission Created
02-19-03: Membership; Terms Of Office
02-19-05: Organization
02-19-07: Duties
02-19-01: COMMISSION CREATED:
   There is hereby created and established a commission to be known as the
Caldwell traffic commission. (Ord. 2861, 2-22-2011)
02-19-03: MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
   (1)   Membership: The Caldwell traffic commission shall consist of the
public works director, the city engineer, the chief of police, the fire chief,
the planning and zoning director, the street superintendent or their designees
and one at large member.
   (2)      Terms Of Office: The at large member shall be appointed for a term
of three (3) years commencing January 1 and ending on December 31 by the mayor
and city council. Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment in the same manner
and shall serve only for the remainder of the term which is vacant. (Ord. 2861,
2-22-2011)
02-19-05: ORGANIZATION:
The commission shall meet quarterly (four (4) times per year). Additional
meetings may be called for by the Public Works Director, as necessary. The
public works director shall serve as chair of the commission and the chief of
police shall serve as the vice chair of the commission. The chair shall preside
at meetings of the commission. The vice chair shall, in the absence of the
chair, perform the duties of the chair. All meetings of the commission shall be
open to the public and follow the requirements of Idaho's open meeting laws 1
. The commission shall keep minutes and other appropriate written records. A
simple majority of commission members present at any given meeting constitutes
a quorum. (Ord. 2861, 2-22-2011; Ord. 3405, 3-21-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. IC title 67, chapter 23.
02-19-07: DUTIES:
   The commission is formed for the purpose of making recommendations to the
mayor and city council in all matters pertaining to traffic safety. (Ord. 2861,
2-22-2011)
ARTICLE 21
TRUSTEES OF THE CITY OF CALDWELL EMPLOYEE BENEFIT PLAN TRUST AGREEMENT
SECTION:
02-21-01: Appointment; Provisions Of Trust Agreement On File
02-21-01: APPOINTMENT; PROVISIONS OF TRUST AGREEMENT ON FILE:
   This section codifies, ratifies and recognizes the appointment of trustees
pursuant to the "city of Caldwell employee benefit plan trust agreement"
(referred to hereinafter in this section as "trust agreement"), executed on or
about September 2, 2008. The purpose of said document, in part, and by its own
stated terms, is "to provide for the payment of eligible expenses incurred by
plan participants for certain services". The trust agreement appoints as the
initial trustees: 1) the human resources director for the city of Caldwell and
2) the finance director/treasurer for the city of Caldwell. It further provides
that the trustees shall be allowed to appoint ex officio members or
administrative staff as needed, upon notification to city council. The trust
agreement further contains provisions relating to the term of each trustee, the
processes for resignation or removal and for the appointment of successor
trustees, notice for and meetings of trustees, voting, powers, recordkeeping,
liability, and providing for the promulgation of rules and regulations
pertaining to the sound and efficient administration of the trust agreement. A
copy of the trust agreement, as it may be amended from time to time, and
information relating to the identity of currently serving trustees shall be
available to the public upon request made to the city clerk. (Ord. 2940, 7-1-
2013)
ARTICLE 25
AUDIT COMMITTEE
SECTION:
02-25-01: Creation; Composition
02-25-03: Meetings
02-25-05: Authority and Responsibility
02-25-07: Audit Committee Bylaws
02-25-01: CREATION; COMPOSITION:
   (1)   Creation: The Council hereby constitutes and establishes an Audit
Committee.
   (2)   Composition: The Committee shall be comprised of five (5) members
appointed by the Council, two (2) of whom are members of the Council Finance
Committee, and three (3) (the independent members) who are independent of
management and the independent auditor. The independent members' terms shall be
three (3) years and staggered so that the Committee annually includes a new
independent member and independent members with one (1) and two (2) years'
service. One (1) independent member shall be appointed Chairman by the Council.
(Ord. 1898, 5-6-91)
02-25-03: MEETINGS:
   (1)   Meeting Times: The Audit Committee is to meet at least two (2) times
per year unless additional meeting(s) are necessary, as determine by the
Finance Director.
   (2)   Attendance: Members of the Audit Committee are to be present at all
meetings. As necessary or desirable, the Chairman may request that members of
management, the director of internal audit and representatives of the
independent auditor be present at a meeting of the Committee.
   (3)   Minutes: Minutes of each meeting are to be prepared and approved by
the Committee members and provided to the Council. Approved minutes are to be
available for public inspection. (Ord. 1898, 5-6-91; Ord. 3405, 3-21-2022)
02-25-05: AUTHORITY AND RESPONSIBILITY:
   The Audit Committee is to serve as a focal point for communication between
the Council, the independent auditor, internal auditor and management, as their
duties relate to financial accounting, reporting and internal controls and
compliance. The Audit Committee is to assist the Council in fulfilling its
responsibilities as to accounting policies and reporting practices of the City
and sufficiency of auditing relative thereto. It is to be the Council's
principal agent in assuring the independence of the City's independent
auditors, the integrity of management and the adequacy of disclosures to the
public. However, the opportunity for the independent auditors to meet with the
entire Council as needed is not to be restricted. The Committee shall oversee
and advise the Council and management on the selection of independent auditors.
(Ord. 1989, 5-6-91)
02-25-07: AUDIT COMMITTEE BYLAWS:
   The Committee's operational guidelines are set down in the Audit Committee
bylaws and may be amended, after consultation with the Council, by a majority
vote of the independent members. The authority and responsibility of the Audit
Committee and the appointment and terms of members are designated in the bylaws
and are incorporated herein by reference. (Ord. 1898, 5-6-91)
ARTICLE 27
CALDWELL EXECUTIVE AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
02-27-01: Creation And Composition
02-27-03: Membership; Appointment; Terms; And Vacancies
02-27-05: Duties And Responsibilities
02-27-07: Meetings
02-27-09: Officers
02-27-11: Records
02-27-01: CREATION AND COMPOSITION:
An Airport Advisory Board is hereby created, consisting of not less than three
(3) nor more than seven (7) voting members, all of whom shall be appointed by
the Mayor and approved by a majority vote of the City Council. The members of
the board shall serve without compensation. The term of office for each member
shall be for a period of three (3) years. The Board shall elect a Chairperson
and Vice-Chairperson. The Chairperson shall preside and direct all board
meetings. In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall preside
and direct the meeting. The City of Caldwell's Director of Aviation, or their
designee, shall serve in a non-voting capacity as a Facilitator at board
meetings. The facilitator is responsible for assisting the Chairperson in the
process of the meeting(s).
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023; amd. Ord. 3540-A, 11-21-2023)
02-27-03: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERMS; AND VACANCIES:
   (1)   Membership: The membership of the Advisory Board shall be composed of:
      At least one (1), but not more than three (3), members that are general
aviation users that do not affiliate with a commercial entity at the Caldwell
Executive Airport. A minimum of one (1) of these members shall be a resident of
Caldwell or live within the Caldwell City Impact Area.
      At least one (1), but not more than three (3), members that are owner/
operators of a commercial entity at the Caldwell Executive Airport. A minimum
of one (1) of these members shall be a resident of Caldwell or live within the
Caldwell City Impact Area.
      One (1) member shall also be a member of the City Council, assigned to
the Board.
      The Board is encouraged to involve young aviators and may have one (1)
additional non-voting member who is a Caldwell resident under the age of 18.
      Staggered terms should be implemented to ensure that no more than three
(3) board member terms expire in any given year. No member shall serve more
than three (3) full consecutive terms.
   (2)   Attendance: Board members are expected to attend as many meetings as
possible. Missing multiple meetings throughout the calendar year, or missing
two (2) or more consecutive meetings without prior consent from the Chairperson
shall be grounds for being removed from the Board by the City Council.
   (3)   Removal: Removal of any board member(s) shall take place as stated in
Caldwell City Code Chapter 2 Article 6.
   (4)   The youth member shall be appointed to a term of up to one year and
may be reappointed for up to two (2) successive terms not to exceed a sitting
time of three (3) years.
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023; amd. Ord. 3540-A, 11-21-2023)
02-27-05: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
It shall be the duty of the Board to provide recommendations to the City based
on the Airport's needs based on an analysis of how they can assist the City in
implementing FAA-approved Master Plan and Grant Assurance projects to assist in
the orderly and efficient administration and operation of the Caldwell
Executive Airport. This may include:
   (1)   To study the economic and physical conditions and problems in
connection with the maintenance, operation, regulation, control, and use of
Caldwell Executive Airport;
   (2)   To propose recommendations for the operation, control, and use of
Caldwell Executive Airport, and the maintenance and operation of hangars,
repair shops, depots, taxi strips, and all other facilities and utilities
required, necessary, or convenient for the proper orderly and efficient
administration, operation, superintendence and control of the Caldwell
Executive Airport;
   (3)   To propose recommendations and suggestions for the purpose of planning
for further growth, development, and regulation of the Caldwell Executive
Airport in order to promote the public interest, convenience, and welfare in
the administration and operation of the Caldwell Executive Airport, as well as
to promote business activities to serve as a catalyst for economic development
throughout the City and region;
   (4)   All proposals for changes to current Airport Rules and Regulations and
Minimum Standards proposed by the Board will be reviewed by the Board
Facilitator, Chairperson, and Vice-Chairperson to ensure FAA compliance.
Reviewed proposals shall be submitted to City Council for approval and
ratification and, after such approval and ratification shall have the force and
effect of ordinance.
   (5)   To advise the City of Caldwell's Aviation Administration regarding
rules and regulations for aircraft traffic regulation, airport facilities, and
runway improvements.
   (6)   To formulate, propose, and recommend such rules and regulations as are
necessary or desirable to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter.
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023; amd. Ord. 3540-A, 11-21-2023)
02-27-07: MEETINGS:
The Board shall meet on a regular basis, no less than once per quarter.
Additional meetings may be called by the Chairperson, city staff, or at the
request of the Mayor upon a minimum of seven (7) calendar days written notice
to all members of the Board. The facilitator, in conjunction with the
Chairperson, shall prepare the agenda for each meeting. Complete minutes shall
be kept by the Secretary of the board. Unless otherwise noticed, all Board
meetings shall take place at Hubler Terminal at the Caldwell Executive Airport.
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023; amd. Ord. 3540-A, 11-21-2023)
02-27-09: OFFICERS:
   (1)   Chairperson: The Chairperson is responsible for the meeting's outcomes
and work product.
   (2)   Vice-Chairperson: The vice-chairperson stands in for the chair in his/
her absence.
   (3)   Secretary: The Director of Aviation, or their designee, shall act as
Secretary for all meetings. They shall be responsible for keeping minutes of
each meeting and shall provide said minutes to the Facilitator after each
meeting for them to be distributed to the Board.
   (4)   The Board shall elect a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson from current
voting board members, excluding the City Council member.
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023; amd. Ord. 3540-A, 11-21-2023)
02-27-11: RECORDS:
The Recorder (Board Facilitator) shall take written or media record of meeting
proceedings and produce official minutes of said record within five (5)
business days from meeting completion showing the discussion topics and outcome
of each meeting and other official actions.
(Ord. 3540, 10-3-2023)
