ARTICLE 32
PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
02-32-01: Commission Created
02-32-02: Membership
02-32-03: Terms Of Office
02-32-04: Organization
02-32-05: Powers; Duties
02-32-01: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a commission to be known as the City of
Caldwell's Parks and Recreation Commission. (Ord. 3508, 6-6-2023)
02-32-02: MEMBERSHIP:
The Caldwell Parks and Recreation Commission shall consist of not less than
three (3) nor more than seven (7) voting members including one (1) member of
the city council. An appointed member of the commission must reside in the city
and must remain a resident of the city during service on the commission. All
members shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by majority vote of the
city council. Appointment of one (1) youth advisory member is welcome and
encouraged, with the term of office expiring on August 31 of each year. (Ord.
3508, 6-6-2023)
02-32-03: TERMS OF OFFICE:
The term of office for members shall not be more or less than three (3) years,
provided however, that at the expiration of said term of office, the member
shall be eligible for two (2) additional consecutive reappointments, each for
one full term in addition to the original term already served. No person shall
serve more than two (2) full consecutive terms without specific concurrence by
two-thirds (2/3) of the council adopted by motion and recorded in the minutes.
In no case shall any person serve more than three (3) full consecutive terms.
Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of terms shall be
filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members may be removed
pursuant to Caldwell City Code Chapter 2, Article 6. (Ord. 3508, 6-6-2023)
02-32-04: ORGANIZATION:
The commission shall meet monthly, with an exception being made should a
meeting for that month be unnecessary. Additional meetings may be called for by
the Parks and Recreation Director, as necessary. The commission shall elect a
chairperson and create and fill any other office it may deem necessary. The
chairperson shall preside at meetings of the commission. The vice chairperson
shall, in the absence of the chairperson, perform the duties of the
chairperson. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public and
follow the requirements of Idaho's open meeting laws. Executive sessions may be
closed by the presiding officer pursuant to Idaho Code, Section 74-206.
A member of Caldwell's Parks and Recreation staff shall keep minutes and other
appropriate written records on behalf of the commission. A simple majority of
commission members present at any given meeting constitutes a quorum. (Ord.
3508, 6-6-2023)
02-32-05: POWERS; DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Commission to recommend and make suggestions to the
Council regarding:
   (1)   The formation of new parks and acquisition of land.
   (2)   The development of new pathways.
   (3)   The renovation and expansion of current City parks.
   (4)   The implementation or updating of park policies and recreation
programming. (Ord. 3508, 6-6-2023)
ARTICLE 33
INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
SECTION:
02-33-01: Purpose
02-33-03: Authority
02-33-01: PURPOSE:
   The industrial development corporation was created by the city of Caldwell
pursuant to title 50, chapter 27, Idaho Code (the "act"), for the purposes set
forth in the act, to promote employment, encourage the development of new jobs,
maintain and supplement the capital investments in industry that currently
exist in the city of Caldwell, encourage future employment by ensuring future
capital investment, attract environmentally sound industry, protect and enhance
the quality of natural resources and the environment, and to promote the
products and conservation of energy. (Ord. 2899, 2-21-2012)
02-33-03: AUTHORITY:
   The powers and authority of the industrial development corporation are
provided in Idaho Code, including, but not limited to, those powers set forth
in section 50-2708 and the remainder of the act, as amended, to the extent said
powers are not limited by ordinance 1633 of the city of Caldwell or by the
industrial development corporation's charter, bylaws and/or rules and
regulations. (Ord. 2899, 2-21-2012)

ARTICLE 37
DESIGN REVIEW COMMISSION
SECTION:
02-37-01: Commission Created
02-37-02: Appointment; Term
02-37-03: Organization
02-37-04: Meetings
02-37-05: Powers, Duties, And Responsibilities
02-37-01: COMMISSION CREATED:
   (1)   There shall be a design review commission for the city, which shall be
known and designated as the "design review commission" (DRC). (Ord. 3083, 4-17-
2017)
02-37-02: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
   (1)   The DRC shall consist of at least three (3) and no more than seven (7)
commissioners, all of whom shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of
the city council. Appointed members of the commissions shall live or work in
the city or in the city's impact area during the full term of service.
Commissioners shall have a background and interest in community design such as
architects, planners, engineers, builders, developers, historians,
businesspersons, and property owners.
   When a vacancy occurs for any reason other than an expired term a new
commissioner shall be appointed to complete the remainder of that term.
Commissioners shall be appointed to two (2) and three (3) year terms that are
equally staggered. Subsequent terms shall be three (3) years in length for all
commissioners. (Ord. 3083, 4-17-2017; amd. Ord. 3627, 8-19-2024)
02-37-03: ORGANIZATION:
   (1)   The DRC shall elect its own chair and vice chair. Election of officers
shall take place annually during the first meeting of the calendar year. During
the absence of the chair, the vice chair shall assume the duties of the chair.
The planning and zoning director, or a designated representative, shall serve
as secretary and shall store recordings and produce accurate minutes of all
commission meetings. (Ord. 3083, 4-17-2017)
02-37-04: MEETINGS:
   (1)   The DRC shall hold meetings on an as needed basis. The DRC shall
decide on the date and time of the meeting. Regular meetings shall at all times
be open to the public.
(Ord. 3083, 4-17-2017; amd. Ord. 3542, 10-17-2023)
02-37-05: POWERS, DUTIES, AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   (1)   The DRC shall review projects requested by the applicant for
compliance with design review standards within sections
10-12-05, "City Center Design Requirements", and 10-12-06, "City Center Indian
Creek Corridor Design Requirements", of this code.
   (2)   The DRC's jurisdiction is limited to new construction, building
additions, or exterior renovations on properties in the city center zoning
district as determined on the official zoning map for the city of Caldwell.
   (3)   The DRC shall review projects and either approve, approve with
conditions, or deny such application. The planning and zoning director, or a
designated representative, shall then notify the applicant in writing of the
decision.
   (4)   Staff decisions may be appealed to the DRC, and conversely DRC
decisions may be appealed to the Caldwell city council for review and decision.
Appeals shall be filed in accordance will all Caldwell city ordinances.
   (5)   The powers, duties and responsibilities of the DRC shall comply with
the state of Idaho local land use planning act of 1975. (Ord. 3083, 4-17-2017)
ARTICLE 38
DOWNTOWN PARKING ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
02-38-01: Commission Created
02-38-02: Duties and Responsibilities Of The Board
02-38-03: Procedures; Rules; Meetings; Officers
02-38-01: COMMISSION CREATED:
   (1)   Creation: There is hereby created and established a downtown parking
advisory board which shall consist of not less than three (3) and no more than
seven (7) voting board members.
   (2)   Expiration: The advisory board shall be active and perform the duties
as specified in this article for a period of two (2) years from the effective
date of this ordinance. The board will sunset on February 18, 2027, unless
reestablished or extended by formal action of the City Council.
   (3)   Voting Members: All voting members shall be appointed by the mayor and
confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. Appointed members of the
board shall meet at least one of the following criteria:
      A.   A citizen of Caldwell with their main residence located within
Caldwell city limits;
      B.   Be the owner of real property located within the Caldwell Downtown
Business District; or
      C.   Be the owner of an active business within the Caldwell Downtown
Business District. An owner of property shall mean the title holder, purchaser
under a contract for deed, lessee.
   (4)   Non-Voting Members: In addition, the mayor shall assign a city council
member to sit on the Board as a non-voting council liaison. The City of
Caldwell's Community Development Director, or their designee, shall serve in a
non-voting capacity as a Facilitator at board meetings. The facilitator is
responsible for assisting the Chairperson in the process of the meeting(s).
   (5)   Members; Initial Term: All board members shall be appointed for an
initial two (2) year term. After two (2) years, if the City Council votes for
the advisory board to continue and remain active in its duties, existing board
member terms may be extended, or new board members may be appointed.
   (6)   Compensation: The members of the board shall serve without
compensation.
   (7)   Vacancies: Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration
of terms shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. (Ord.
3657, 2-18-2025)
02-38-02: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE BOARD:
   The Downtown Parking Advisory Board will advise and make policy
recommendations to City staff and City Council on all aspects of public parking
within the Caldwell Downtown Districts. The purpose of the board is to provide
citizen and property owner input into the policy decisions for the City related
to all aspects of public parking, including but not limited to on-street
parking, parking lots, and parking fees. (Ord. 3657, 2-18-2025)
02-38-03: MEETINGS:
   (1)   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings shall be scheduled no less than
once a quarter. Regular meetings shall at all times be open to the public.
   (2)   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the Chairperson,
city staff, or at the request of the mayor upon a minimum of five (5) calendar
days written notice to all members of the Board.
   (3)   Record: The facilitator, in conjunction with the Chairperson, shall
keep a record of its attendance, proceedings and actions, and prepare the
agenda for each meeting. Complete minutes shall be kept by the Facilitator of
the board, or their designee.
   (4)   Quorum Present: In case there shall be no quorum present on the day
fixed for a regular or special meeting, the commission members present may
adjourn to a specified date and time until a quorum is obtained.
   (5)   Attendance: Board members are expected to attend as many meetings as
possible. Missing multiple meetings throughout the calendar year or missing two
(2) or more consecutive meetings without prior consent from the Chairperson
shall be grounds for being removed from the Board by the City Council.
   (6)   Removal: Removal of any board member(s) shall take place as stated in
Caldwell City Code Chapter 2 Article 6.
   (7)   Election of Officers: The Board shall elect its own chair and vice
chair. Election of officers shall take place annually during the first meeting
of the calendar year. During the absence of the chair, the vice chair shall
assume the duties of the chair.
   (8)   Chairperson: The Chairperson shall preside over and direct all
meetings of the board. The chairperson shall be responsible for ensuring that
all meetings are conducted in an orderly and effective manner.
   (9)   Vice-Chairperson: In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-
Chairperson shall assume the duties of the Chairperson. (Ord. 3657, 2-18-2025)

03-01-01: OFFICERS TO TAKE OATH OF OFFICE:
   The various officers of the City shall take and subscribe before some
officer authorized to administer oaths such oath as is required by law of
municipal officers 1 ; which oath shall be filed with the Clerk. No officer
shall enter upon the performance of the duties of his office until he shall
have subscribed and filed such oath as required herein. (Ord. 913, 7-6-1962)
 
Notes
1 1. IC 59-401.
03-01-03: BONDS, CERTAIN CITY OFFICERS':
   (1)   The Clerk, Treasurer, Finance Director, and Chief of Police, before
entering upon the duties of their offices shall file with the Clerk, good and
sufficient bonds with responsible sureties, in amounts as may be determined and
approved by the Council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of their respective offices.
   (2)   All other employees of the City whose duties involve the handling of
monies shall be covered by blanket bond in amounts as may be determined and
approved by the City Council. (Ord. 913, 7-6-1962; Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff.
8-23-2022)
03-01-05: MAYOR AND COUNCIL SALARIES:
   (1)   Elected Officials:
      A.   Mayor: The annual salary of the Mayor shall be as follows:
         1.   Commencing January 1, 2024, the Mayor shall receive a biweekly
salary in the sum of three thousand seven hundred fifty two dollars
($3,752.00).
         2.   Commencing January 1, 2026, the Mayor shall receive a biweekly
salary in the sum of three thousand nine hundred forty dollars ($3,940.00).
      B.   Council: The annual salary of each member of the City Council shall
be as follows:
         1.   Commencing January 1, 2024, each member of the City Council shall
receive a biweekly salary in the sum of four hundred fifty one dollars
($451.00).
         2.   Commencing January 1, 2026, each member of the City Council shall
receive a biweekly salary in the sum of four hundred seventy four dollars
($474.00).
   (2)   Appointive Officers: All officers and employees of the City, other
than elected officials, shall be paid salaries or fees in such amounts as may
be set from time to time by the City Council. (Ord. 1656, 8-31-1983; Ord. 3104,
8-7-2017; Ord. 3223, 7-15-2019; Ord. 3365, 8-16-2021; Ord. 3523, 8-1-2023)

The mayor shall appoint, subject to the approval of the majority of the full
city council: a city clerk, city attorney, public works director, police chief,
fire chief, director of finance, city treasurer, director of aviation, human
resources director, community development director, and parks and recreation
director. The mayor may appoint, with the approval of the majority of the full
city council, such other officers as deemed necessary for the efficient
operation of the business of the municipality.
(Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011; Ord. 3495, 4-4-2023; Ord. 3516, 7-5-2023; Ord. 3617, 8-5-

of officers shall coincide with the fiscal year. All other boards and
committees shall coincide with the calendar year.
(Ord. 1711, 10-14-1985; amd. Ord. 3516, 7-5-2023)
03-03-05: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
   The mayor shall remove from office, by and with the consent and advice of
four (4) members of the city council, any appointed officer of the city, any
member of the board or commission whose removal from office is not otherwise
provided for.
(Ord. 1118, 12-4-1967)
03-03-07: DESIGNATION OF DUTIES:
   Whenever there is a question or dispute as to the respective duties or
powers of any appointed officer of the city, the question or dispute shall be
settled by the mayor, and the mayor shall have the power to delegate to any
appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer
has been directed to perform that duty.
(1962 Code § 1-4-9)
ARTICLE 5
MAYOR
SECTION:
03-05-01: Election
03-05-03: Conflicting Interests
03-05-05: Work Hours; Office Space
03-05-07: Vacancies In Office
03-05-09: Powers And Duties
03-05-13: Decisions Of Council
03-05-01: ELECTION:
   The mayor shall be elected for a four (4) year term and shall serve until
his successor is elected and qualified as provided by statute. A majority of
the votes for any candidate running for the office of mayor shall be required
for election to that office. In the event no candidate receives a majority of
the votes cast, there shall be a runoff election between the two (2) candidates
receiving the highest number of votes cast. Said runoff election shall be
conducted in cooperation with county clerk as provided by statute. (Ord. 1048,
8-2-1965; Ord. 3322, 4-5-2021)
03-05-03: CONFLICTING INTERESTS:
   The mayor shall not engage in any economic endeavor that conflicts with the
duties of the office. Upon being sworn in as mayor, the mayor shall resign any
employment, appointed position or elected position, including a city council
position, with the city of Caldwell. (Ord. 2701, 9-17-2007)
03-05-05: WORK HOURS; OFFICE SPACE:
   (1)   Work Hours: The mayor shall devote not less than forty (40) hours per
week to performing the duties of the office, excepting therefrom holiday and
vacation periods as established by the mayor and council.
   (2)   Office Space: The mayor and council shall provide offices in the city
hall for the mayor. (1962 Code, Section 1-4-5; Ord. 1825, 10-2-1989)
03-05-07: VACANCIES IN OFFICE:
   In case of a temporary vacancy in the office of mayor due to absence or
disability, the president of the council shall exercise the office of mayor
during such disability or temporary absence and until the mayor shall return.
When a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor by reason of death, resignation or
permanent disability, the city council shall fill the vacancy from within or
without the council as may be deemed in the best interests of the city, and
appointee shall serve until the next general city election, at which election a
mayor shall be elected for the full four (4) year term. (1962 Code, Sections 1-
4-10 and 1-4-11; 1994 Code)
03-05-09: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   Power and Authority: The Mayor shall be the Chief Executive Officer of
the City, shall preside over the meetings of the Council and shall perform such
duties as may be required of him by law. He shall have supervision over all of
the executive officers and employees of the City and shall have the power and
authority to inspect all books and records pertaining to City affairs and kept
by any officer or employee of the City.
   (2)   Membership on Committees and Commissions: The Mayor shall be an ex-
officio member of all committees and commissions existing under the City code.
   (3)   Messages to Council: The Mayor shall deliver to the Council such
information and such recommendations as, in his opinion, will be of benefit to
the City.
   (4)   Special Meetings: The Mayor shall have the power to call special
meetings of the City Council, the object of which shall be submitted to the
Council in writing; the call and object, as well as the disposition thereof,
shall be entered upon the journal by the Clerk. One-half (1/2) plus one of the
members of the full Council shall also have the power to call special meetings
of the City Council, the object of which shall be submitted to the Council in
writing; the call and object, as well as the disposition thereof, shall be
entered upon the journal of the Clerk.
   (5)   Mayor to Sign Contacts: The Mayor is authorized and empowered to sign
his name, official for and in behalf of, the municipality on all contracts,
documents and papers to which the municipality is a party, and to require that
the conditions of any instrument are faithfully performed. The Mayor is
authorized and empowered to enter into Standard Form Lease Agreements with
tenants at the Caldwell Industrial Airport, said Standard Form Lease Agreement
being adopted, from time to time, by resolution of the Caldwell City Council.
The Mayor may borrow money on the credit of the municipality when so authorized
by the Council.
   (6)   Jurisdiction: The Mayor shall have the jurisdiction over all places
within five (5) miles of the corporate limits of the municipality for the
enforcement of any health or quarantine ordinances and regulations and shall
have jurisdiction in all matters, excepting taxation, within one (1) mile of
the corporate limits of the municipality.
   (7)   Requiring Aid: The Mayor is hereby authorized to call on every male
inhabitant of the municipality of the age of twenty-one (21) or over to aid him
in enforcing the law.
   (8)   Additional Duties: The Mayor shall perform all of the duties required
of Mayors under the provisions of Chapter 3, Title 50, Idaho Code, and such
other duties as may be reasonably required by the Council of the City.
   (9)   Drought Conditions: The Mayor is hereby authorized to declare the
existence of drought like conditions and, with the advice of the Public Works
Director, to defer landscaping requirements for development until a date
certain, said date to extend no further than six (6) months from the date of
such declaration without the consent of the City Council, with such conditions
as the Mayor may deem appropriate. (1962 Code, Sections 1-4-6, 1-4-10, 1-4-14,
1-4-17 and 1-4-21; Ord. 1118, 12-4-67; Ord. 1188, 3-16-70; 1994 Code; Ord.
3321, 1-19-21; Ord. 3361, 8-2-2021)
03-05-11: DECISIONS OF COUNCIL:
   (1)   Vote: The Mayor shall have the vote on any decision to be made by the
Council only when the Council is equally divided.
   (2)   Veto: The Mayor shall have the power to veto or sign any law passed by
the Council; provided, that any law vetoes by the Mayor may be passed over his
veto by a vote of two-thirds of the elected members of the Council, and should
the Mayor neglect or refuse to sign any law and return the same with his
objections, in writing, at the next regular meeting of the Council, the same
shall become a law without his signature. (1962 Code, Sections 1-4-12 and 1-4-
13; 1994 Code)
ARTICLE 7
CITY CLERK
SECTION:
03-07-01: Appointment and Supervision
03-07-03: Qualifications and Job Requirements
03-07-05: Powers and Duties
03-07-01: APPOINTMENT AND SUPERVISION:
   There is hereby created the position of City Clerk, a position which shall
be filled by appointment as provided in Section
 03-03-01 of this Chapter. The City Clerk shall work under the general guidance
and direction of the Mayor. (Ord. 1763, 12-7-87)
03-07-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIRMENTS:
   (1)   Required Skills and Knowledge:
      A.   The City Clerk shall be or have:
         1.   Skilled in data entry, typing and general office procedures and
filing systems.
         2.   Good knowledge of the organization and functions of City
government.
         3.   Ability to acquire knowledge of State and local statutes
pertaining to Council proceedings.
         4.   Ability to write clear and accurate reports on complex subjects.
   (2)   Acceptable Education and Experience:
      A.   High school graduate or equivalent.
      B.   College level courses in business and public administration
preferred.
      C.   Considerable experience in City government desirable or an
equivalent combination of education and experience.
   (3)   Necessary Special Requirements: The City Clerk must be bondable and
must maintain a valid Idaho driver's license. (Ord. 1763, 12-7-87)
03-07-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   General Statement of Duties: The City Clerk is responsible for all of
the official documents of the municipality and shall act as Clerk of the
governing body. The Clerk performs other duties as assigned or required by the
position.
   (2)   Supervision Exercised: The City Clerk supervises a small staff of the
City Clerk's office.
   (3)   Illustrative Examples of Duties: The City Clerk:
      A.   Directs the custody of all ordinances, resolutions, contracts and
all other official documents of the City.
      B.   Directs the updating of the City code.
      C.   Attests the Mayor's signature on official documents of the City.
      D.   Administers official oaths for the City.
      E.   Maintains a legislative history record of all items which have
appeared before the Council.
      F.   Supervises the microfilming and maintenance of all permanent records
of the City.
      G.   Directs the conduct of all municipal elections 1 .
      H.   Attends all City Council meetings and acts as Clerk of the Council
at these meetings.
      I.   Directs the preparation of the official minutes of Council meetings.
      J.   Is responsible for all details of Council meetings; prepares and
keeps up to date all records and documents of Council business; prepares
Council agenda; notifies persons when they are in appearance at meetings and
sees that the required documents are assembled and available.
      K.   Notifies interested parties of Council action.
      L.   Publishes reports, ordinances and legal notices; maintains custody
of official Council minutes and answers inquiries regarding Council activities;
prepares periodic and special reports of Council activities.
      M.   Prepares estimated budget requirements; prepares specialized
technical and financial reports. (Ord. 1763, 12-7-87)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1, article 7 of this code.

ARTICLE 11
HUMAN RESOURCES DIRECTOR
SECTION:
03-11-01: Appointment And Supervision
03-11-03: Qualifications And Job Requirements
03-11-05: Powers And Duties
03-11-01: APPOINTMENT AND SUPERVISION:
   There is hereby created the position of human resources director, a position
which shall be filled by appointment as provided in section
03-03-01 of this chapter. The human resources director shall work under the
general guidance and direction of the mayor. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
03-11-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Required skills and knowledge:
      A.   Good oral and written communication skills and comprehensive
knowledge of office administration principles and practices.
      B.   Comprehensive knowledge of the general principles of local, state
and federal government organization and operation.
      C.   Ability to plan, direct, organize, manage and implement the city's
compensation and benefits package and personnel policies; ensure compliance
with all federal and state employment practice laws; prepare and deliver oral
presentations; maintain records and prepare reports; prioritize and schedule
work; interpret, apply and explain laws, policies and procedures; and work
independently with little direction.
   (2)   Acceptable education and experience:
      A.   Graduation from an accredited college or university with a
bachelor's or higher degree in public administration, business administration,
or other related field; and
      B.   Considerable experience in public management and administration;
      C.   Any equivalent combination of experience, education and training
which provides the knowledge, skills and abilities necessary to perform the
work. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
03-11-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   General Statement Of Duties: The human resources director plans,
directs, organizes, manages and implements the city's compensation and benefits
package and personnel policies; coordinates with the city officials, department
managers and employees; prepares and develops annual budgets and monitors
expenditures; develops, presents and implements training and educational
materials and programs for city employees; reviews employment laws and policies
to ensure compliance; develops and administers the city's compensation and pay
plans.
   (2)   Supervision Exercised: The human resources director exercises
oversight for all personnel related activities. He/she works closely with the
mayor, officials and department heads to coordinate, implement and ensure
policy compliance. Direct supervision is exercised over the human resources
staff. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)

DIRECTOR OF AVIATION
SECTION:
03-12-01: Appointment
03-12-03: Powers And Duties
03-12-01: APPOINTMENT:
   The Director of Aviation shall be appointed as provided in Section
03-03-01 of this Chapter; and shall hold office for the duration of the

Council. (Ord. 3495, 4- 4-2023)
03-12-03: POWERS AND DUTIES:

   (3)   The Director of Aviation shall report directly to the Mayor.
   (4)   The Director of Aviation supervises the Airport Manager and
individuals employed as administrative assistants and other office staff
assisting with the management of the Caldwell Executive Airport. (Ord. 3495, 4-
4-2023)
ARTICLE 13
CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
03-13-01: Appointment
03-13-03: Powers and Duties
03-13-01: APPOINTMENT:
   The City Attorney shall be appointed as provided in Section
03-03-01 of this Chapter. He shall hold office for the duration of his
appointment unless sooner removed by the Mayor with the concurrence of the
Council. (1962 Code, Section 1-8-1; 1994 Code)
03-13-03: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   Advice: The Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the municipality
and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the municipality
whenever requested to do so by any municipal official. Upon request by the
Mayor or by the City Council, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing.
   (2)   Suits and Actions: The City Attorney shall prosecute and defend any
and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the municipality may be a
party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by
any officer of the municipality on behalf of the municipality, or in the
capacity of such person as an officer of the municipality.
   (3)   Enforce Judgments: It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to see to
the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor
of the municipality, and of all similar interlocutory orders.
   (4)   Special Assessments: It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to see
to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation
proceedings.
   (5)   Ordinances and Documents: It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to
draft or supervise the phraseology of any contract, lease or other document or
instrument, to which the municipality may be a party and, upon the request of
the City Council, to draft ordinances covering any subjects within the power of
the municipality. (1962 Code, Sections 1-8-2 through 1-8-6)
ARTICLE 15
CITY TREASURER-FINANCE DIRECTOR
SECTION:
03-15-01: General Statement Of Duties
03-15-03: Supervision Received
03-15-05: Supervision Exercised
03-15-07: Essential Duties
03-15-09: Other Essential Duties (Illustrative Only)
03-15-11: Required Knowledge, Skills, And Abilities
03-15-13: Acceptable Experience And Training
03-15-01: GENERAL STATEMENT OF DUTIES:
   Performs a variety of administrative, supervisory, and professional tasks
related to the directing, controlling and monitoring of the day-to-day cash
management activities of the City of Caldwell; provides highly responsible and
complex administrative and policy support to the organization; assists city
departments in cash management and related financing activities; makes
recommendations regarding the implementation of cash procedures and policies;
and performs related work as required. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-03: SUPERVISION RECEIVED:
   Appointed by the mayor with consent of the city council. Works under the
direct supervision of the mayor and the council's finance committee. (Ord.
3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-05: SUPERVISION EXERCISED:
   Hires, trains, supervises, and evaluates all finance department staff. (Ord.
3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-07: ESSENTIAL DUTIES:
   The Treasurer shall be the custodian of all moneys belonging to the city;
shall account for each fund or appropriation made in its annual budget
appropriation or otherwise directed by the city council. Such accounting shall
track the debits and credits relating thereto; shall render a monthly
accounting to the city council; shall also make available credit and debit
details of all such accounts when required by the mayor or by action of the
governing board; shall make quarterly treasurer's reports for public view;
shall keep a record of all outstanding bonds against the city showing the
number, amount of each, and to whom said bonds were issued and when any bonds
are purchased, paid, or canceled; shall make an annual report; and shall, upon
notification by the state controller, comply with the accounting and fiscal
reporting requirements set forth in the uniform accounting manual for local
governmental entities authorized under section 67-1075, Idaho Code. The
Treasurer shall also have any additional duties described in Idaho Code section
50-208. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-09: OTHER ESSENTIAL DUTIES (ILLUSTRATIVE ONLY):
   (1)   Directs, manages, and evaluates the financial service operations,
programs, and activities of the city;
   (2)   Develops investment strategies in consultation with the finance
director;
   (3)   Prepares the monthly Council Cash Report;
   (4)   Trains city personnel in cash management policies and procedures;
   (5)   Prepares the city's Annual Financial Report and reviews the auditing
procedure to ensure compliance with State and Federal regulations;
   (6)   Coordinates the activities of the audit staff members in cooperation
with other departments to ensure a proper, efficient, and responsible use of
the financial management information system;
   (7)   Directs the strategic planning, policy development, data collections,
and reporting activities of the finance department;
   (8)   Oversees all general city accounting, including monitoring accounts
payables, utility billing, and payroll, and other financial resources;
   (9)   Analyzes the City's daily cash flow to determine the necessary
operating cash balances and invests all excess funds to ensure safety,
liquidity, and yield;
   (10)   Works closely with department directors and managers to provide cash
management policy guidance and to follow-up on director's assignments;
   (11)   Notifies the finance director, Mayor, and department directors on
financial issues;
   (12)   Oversees, reconciles and accounts for all city revenue and monitors
utility account receipts;
   (13)   Accounting Software: Coordinates computer support for financial and
bank software and modules; provides staff training; resolves operation related
issues and staff questions; and assists in establishing security access for
administrative staff;
   (14)   Caldwell Urban Renewal Agency: Assists finance director in audit and
budget preparation;
   (15)   Library: Provides cash management support to the library director,
including recommending and managing investments and maintaining investment
policies;
   (16)   Grants: Files federal and state grant reports and prepares SEFA and
audit schedules;
   (17)   Debt: Responsible for bond covenant compliance and annual reporting;
   (18)   Budget: Prepares initial extended budgeting department reports;
trains city staff in budget report preparation and submission; and uploads and
reconciles adopted budget files into extended budgeting and general ledger;
   (19)   Assists in annual budget preparations; edits, updates, and creates
budget reports; uploads the annual budget tracking software; monitors budget
revenues and disbursements; and prepares monthly Council Revenue and Cash
Report;
   (20)   Monitors budgetary activities and investigates exceptions;
   (21)   Prepares the annual budget amendment, including gathering all dates,
analyzing results, and presenting a final report to the finance director,
mayor, city council, and the public;
   (22)   Provides recommendations to the finance director, city council,
department directors, and city employees on proper internal controls, budgeting
practices, financing methods, and other cash management functions;
   (23)   Responsible for distribution of annual budget;
   (24)   Audit: Prepares year-end statements, audit schedules, worksheets,
cash and investment audit work papers, and footnotes associated with the city's
Annual Finance Report, and provides technical information to auditors;
completes year-end closing entries; assists with audit fieldwork; interfaces
with external auditors to respond to questions or requests for information;
maintains the reporting system within the city's Engagement System and
supporting schedules; and distributes annual audits to Federal Clearing House
agencies;
   (25)   Records closing journal entries to general ledger;
   (26)   Maintains current knowledge of organizational policies and procedures
relating to federal and state policies, directives, and current accounting
standards;
   (27)   Prepares or directs the preparation of financial statements, audit
work papers, financial position forecasts, budget status reports, and other
requested reports;
   (28)   Staff Support: Cross-trains in accounting tasks and all application
modules in Springbrook Financial Software;
   (29)   Hires, trains, supervises, and evaluates all finance department
staff;
   (30)   Keeps immediate supervisor and designated others fully and accurately
informed concerning work progress, including present and potential work
problems and suggestions for new or improved ways of addressing such problems;
   (31)   Attends approved meetings, conferences, workshops, training sessions,
and reviews publications and audio-visual materials to become and remain
current on the principles, practices, and new developments in assigned work
areas;
   (32)   Responds to citizens' questions and comments in a courteous and
timely manner;
   (33)   Trains, assigns, prioritizes, supervises, motivates, and evaluates
the work of assigned employees;
   (34)   Communicates and respects the opinions of others and maintains a
positive and professional working relationship with city officials, employees,
supervisors and others; and
   (35)   Perform all other duties as may be assigned by the Mayor or Mayor and
Council. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-11: REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:
   (1)   Demonstrated knowledge of the principles and practices of public
administration, specifically municipal government and finance;
   (2)   Demonstrated knowledge of the general principles of local, state and
federal government organization and operation;
   (3)   Demonstrated knowledge of banking practices;
   (4)   Demonstrated knowledge of and ability to apply effective management
techniques and budgetary procedures;
   (5)   Demonstrated knowledge of the duties, responsibilities and authorities
of each department within the City;
   (6)   Demonstrated knowledge of the practices, methods and laws related to
municipal bond financing;
   (7)   Thorough knowledge of methods and procedures involved in the receipt
and disbursement of large sums of money;
   (8)   Working knowledge of the principles of supervision;
   (9)   Ability to evaluate complex financial systems and efficiently
formulate and install accounting methods, procedures, forms, and records as it
relates to budgeting;
   (10)   Ability to prepare and explain financial reports;
   (11)   Ability to prepare long-range fiscal forecasts and budgeting;
   (12)   Ability to perform financial analysis;
   (13)   Ability to plan, lay out, supervise, and coordinate the work of a
small staff of employees;
   (14)   Ability to communicate clearly and effectively, both verbally and in
writing;
   (15)   Ability to utilize active listening techniques;
   (16)   Ability to utilize long-range planning skills for the development of
department plans;
   (17)   Ability to deal tactfully with citizens, subordinates, department
staff, and local, state and federal representatives;
   (18)   Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships
with elected officials, City supervisor and employees, business leaders, other
government agencies, and general public;
   (19)   Ability to train, assign, motivate, supervise, and evaluate the work
of others;
   (20)   Ability to operate a personal computer using program applications
appropriate to assigned duties and responsibilities;
   (21)   Ability to quickly learn and put to use new skills and knowledge
brought about by rapidly changing information and/or technology; and
   (22)   Integrity, ingenuity, and inventiveness in the performance of
assigned tasks. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-15-13: ACCEPTABLE EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING:
   (1)   Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's
or master's degree in public administration, finance, or other related field;
and
   (2)   Five (5) years of progressively responsible finance and accounting
experience in public and financial management and administration; or
   (3)   Any equivalent combination of experience, education, and training
which provides the knowledge, skills and abilities necessary to perform the
work. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
ARTICLE 16
CITY FINANCE DIRECTOR
SECTION:
03-16-01: General Statement Of Duties
03-16-03: Supervision Received
03-16-05: Essential Duties
03-16-07: Required Knowledge, Skills, And Abilities
03-16-09: Acceptable Experience And Training
03-16-01: GENERAL STATEMENT OF DUTIES:
   Oversees the financial operations of the City of Caldwell; assists in
driving the city's financial strategy and planning; directs city departments in
financial matters; project reporting; makes recommendations and implements
internal controls, financial procedures, and policies; and performs related
work as required. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-16-03: SUPERVISION RECEIVED:
   Appointed by the mayor with consent of the city council. Works under the
direct supervision of the mayor and the council's finance committee. (Ord.
3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-16-05: ESSENTIAL DUTIES:
   (1)   Plans, develops, and evaluates the operational processes, procedures,
functions, and policies of the finance department;
   (2)   Retains constant awareness of the city's financial position and act to
prevent problems;
   (3)   Manages, trains, assigns, prioritizes, motivates, and evaluates the
work, projects, activities, and sets targets for assigned employees;
   (4)   Conducts analysis to make forecasts and reports to the City Council
and Mayor;
   (5)   Implements the vision, policies, procedures, and capital projects of
the city as directed by the Mayor and City Council;
   (6)   Works closely with department directors and managers to provide
financial policy guidance and to follow-up on mayoral assignments;
   (7)   Initiates and follows through on administrative, budget, and fiscal
planning activities;
   (8)   Develops and directs the implementation of finance related goals,
objectives, policies, procedures, and work practices;
   (9)   Prepares and recommends long-range financial plans for city services
and programs; and develops specific proposals for action on current and future
city needs;
   (10)   Oversees the city's budget by managing the development and
implementation of goals and priorities; and meets with departments to review
work plans and budgeting needs;
   (11)   Establishes appropriate service and staffing levels; and assesses and
monitors staff workload and support systems;
   (12)   Reviews and analyzes financial methods, activities, and performance
to find ways to increase effectiveness and improve results and/or the effect on
economies;
   (13)   Makes clear and concise presentations to the City Council;
   (14)   Presents the Mayor's recommended budgets to the City Council and
general public;
   (15)   Responsible for city municipal financing and bonding; and works with
bonding agencies to initiate and apply for needed financing;
   (16)   Provides recommendations to the City Council, department directors,
accountants, and city employees on proper internal controls, budgeting
practices, financing methods, and other accounting functions;
   (17)   Directs the centralized accounting and reporting function for the
city;
   (18)   Maintains current knowledge of organizational policies and
procedures, federal and state policies and directives, and current accounting
standards;
   (19)   Directs pre-audit and internal audit functions;
   (20)   Serves as a liaison to external independent audits;
   (21)   Responds to information requests from departments on accounting
systems and reporting requirements;
   (22)   Prepares and directs the preparation of the annual budget, business
activity reports, financial position forecasts, and other required reports;
   (23)   Monitors, interprets, and evaluates changes in laws and regulations
related to financial activities and functions;
   (24)   Develops and prepares ordinances, regulations, policies and
procedures, and revisions related to financial activities;
   (25)   Keeps immediate supervisor and designated others fully and accurately
informed concerning work progress, including present and potential work
problems and suggestions for new or improved ways of addressing such problems;
   (26)   Attends approved meetings, conferences, workshops, training sessions,
and reviews publications and audio-visual materials to become and remain
current on the principles, practices, and new developments in assigned work
areas;
   (27)   Responds to citizens' questions and comments in a courteous and
timely manner;
   (28)   Communicates and coordinates regularly with others to maximize the
effectiveness and efficiency of interdepartmental operations and activities;
   (29)   Advises the Mayor and department directors on financial issues and
projects;
   (30)   Establishes financial priorities and objectives which often affect
multiple departments;
   (31)   Creates, organizes, appoints, and directs members of inter-
departmental committees for the purpose of addressing citywide financial or
project related needs;
   (32)   Maintains an effective relationship with the City Council by
recommending financial policies, providing reports, and developing methods for
carrying out the council's intentions that are in compliance with ordinances
and in the best interest of the citizens of Caldwell;
   (33)   Informs and advises the City Council on significant administrative
actions, controversial matters, and public interactions; and
   (34)   Develops, recommends, and implements financial policies to attain the
long and short-range goals of the city. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-16-07: REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:
   (1)   Extensive knowledge of the principles and practices of public
administration, specifically municipal government and finance;
   (2)   Extensive knowledge of the general principles of local, state, and
federal government organization and operation;
   (3)   Thorough knowledge of and ability to apply effective management
techniques and budgetary procedures;
   (4)   Good knowledge of the duties, responsibilities, and authorities of
each department within the city;
   (5)   Good knowledge of economic development, redevelopment, and capital
project theories, practices, and methods;
   (6)   Good knowledge of the practices, methods, and laws related to
municipal bond financing;
   (7)   Ability to evaluate complex financial systems and efficiently
formulate and install accounting methods, procedures, forms, and records as it
relates to budgeting;
   (8)   Ability to prepare informative financial reports;
   (9)   Ability to conduct long-range fiscal planning and budgeting;
   (10)   Ability to perform financial analysis;
   (11)   Ability to communicate clearly and effectively, both verbally and in
writing;
   (12)   Ability to utilize active listening techniques;
   (13)   Ability to plan and organize city operating staff to carry out the
overall goals of the city;
   (14)   Ability to utilize long-range planning skills for the development of
department plans;
   (15)   Ability to deal tactfully with citizens, subordinates, department
staff, and local, state, and federal representatives;
   (16)   Ability to implement and sustain annual work plans of departments;
   (17)   Ability to supervise and direct complex and diverse municipal
operations;
   (18)   Ability to provide sound administrative analysis relating to policy
and management issues;
   (19)   Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships
with council, employees, business leaders, and the general public;
   (20)   Ability to train, assign, motivate, supervise, and evaluate the work
of others;
   (21)   Ability to operate a personal computer using program applications
appropriate to assigned duties and responsibilities;
   (22)   Ability to quickly learn and put to use new skills and knowledge
brought about by rapidly changing information and/or technology;
   (23)   Integrity, ingenuity, and inventiveness in the performance of
assigned tasks. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
03-16-09: ACCEPTABLE EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING:
   (1)   Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's
or master's degree in public administration, finance, or other related field;
and
   (2)   Extensive experience in public and financial management and
administration.
   (3)   Any equivalent combination of experience, education, and training
which provides the knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary to perform the
work. (Ord. 3447, 8-18-2022, eff. 8-23-2022)
ARTICLE 17
CHIEF OF POLICE
SECTION:
03-17-01: Appointment
03-17-03: Qualifications and Job Requirements
03-17-05: Powers and Duties
03-17-01: APPOINTMENT:
   There is hereby created the position of Chief of Police, a position which
shall be filled as provided in Section
03-03-01 of this Chapter. The Chief of Police works under the general guidance
and direction of the Mayor. (Ord. 1766, 12-7-87; 1994 Code)
03-17-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Required Skill, Knowledge and Abilities:
      A.   Considerable knowledge of laws, codes, statutes, ordinances,
policies and procedures and standard police operations.
      B.   Ability to supervise, schedule and coordinate activities of staff.
To represent the Department effectively; to communicate clearly and concisely,
both orally and in writing; to establish and maintain effective working
relationships; and, to make sound decisions.
   (2)   Acceptable Education and Experience: The Chief of Police shall have a
bachelor's degree and ten (10) years of municipal law enforcement experience,
or an equivalent combination of education and experience.
   (3)   Necessary Special Requirements: The Chief of Police shall have and
maintain a valid Idaho driver's license. (Ord. 1766, 12-7-87)
03-17-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   Relating to the Police Department 1 : Responsible for the operation,
administration and coordination of the Caldwell Police Department. Performs
other duties as assigned or required by the position. He/she exercises
supervision of officers and staff directly or through subordinate supervisors.
   (2)   Illustrative Examples of Duties:
      A.   Coordinates activities in law enforcement and security for the
protection of life and property.
      B.   Delegates work activities and duties to division commanders as
appropriate.
      C.   Develops and administers schools and conferences.
      D.   Directs and reviews planning, research and budget activities.
      E.   Administer's the Department's personnel system including
recruitment, promotions, performance evaluations, discipline, counseling and
assignments.
      F.   Provides for the execution of all departmental and City rules,
regulations, policies and procedures.
      G.   Confers with citizens concerning complaints, problems, requests,
suggestions and directs action when appropriate.
      H.   Routinely shares information with Mayor and City Council and submits
monthly report of activity and trends.
      I.   Performs a wide variety of public relations functions.
      J.   Attends meetings, serves on committees and boards, representing the
Department and the City; attends conferences and meeting with representatives
of other law enforcement and allied agencies.
      K.   Develops and maintains liaison with local, State and county law
enforcement agencies and private entities.
      L.   On call twenty-four (24) hours each day. (Ord. 1766, 12-7-87)
   (3)   Recovered and Stolen Property: The Chief of Police and his designated
agents shall have the custody of all lost, abandoned or stolen property
recovered within the municipality. (Ord. 1766, 12-7-87)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2, article 3 for provisions on the police department.
ARTICLE 19
FIRE CHIEF
SECTION:
03-19-01: Appointment
03-19-03: Qualifications and Job Requirements
03-19-05: Powers and Duties
03-19-01: APPOINTMENT:
   There is hereby created the position of Fire Chief, a position which shall
be filled as provided in Section
03-03-01 of this Chapter. The Fire Chief works under the general guidance and
direction of the Mayor. (Ord. 1767, 12-7-87; 1994 Code)
03-19-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Required Skills, Knowledge and Abilities:
      A.   Considerable knowledge of applicable laws, codes, statutes,
ordinances and standard Fire Department operations.
      B.   Ability to:
         1.   Supervise, schedule and coordinate activities of staff and
represent the Department effectively.
         2.   Communicate clearly and concisely both orally and in writing.
         3.   Establish and maintain effective working relationships and sound
decisions.
   (2)   Acceptable Education and Experience: The Fire Chief shall have a
bachelor's degree and ten (10) years of progressive Fire Department experience
or an equivalent combination of education and experience.
   (3)   Necessary Special Requirements: The Fire Chief shall have and maintain
a valid Idaho driver's license. (Ord. 1767, 12-7-87)
03-19-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   Relating to the Fire Department 1 : The Fire Chief is responsible for
the operation, administration and coordination of the Caldwell Fire Department.
Performs other duties as assigned or required by the position. The Fire Chief
supervises all full-time and volunteer personnel of the Department directly or
through subordinate supervisors.
   (2)   Illustrative Examples of Duties:
      A.   Assures the proper manning of shifts.
      B.   Is responsible for hiring, promotion, disciplining and termination
of employees.
      C.   Coordinate with schools and other agencies for fire prevention
training.
      D.   Evaluates the effectiveness of the Department, maintains records and
prepares reports regarding the activities of the Department.
      E.   Oversees the maintenance and upkeep of equipment and building.
      F.   Acts with full command and police authority while at the scene of
fires or alarms of fires.
      G.   Prepares the budgets for the Department, including requisitions for
purchase of new equipment.
      H.   Purchases all Department supplies.
      I.   Provides for the execution of all applicable Departmental and City
rules, regulations, policies and procedures.
      J.   Provides public relations services.
      K.   Shall be on call twenty-four (24) hours each day. (Ord. 1767, 12-7-
87)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2, article 5 of this code for further provisions on the Fire
  Department.

ARTICLE 22
PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR
SECTION:
03-22-01: Appointment
03-22-03: Qualifications And Job Requirements
03-22-05: Powers And Duties
03-22-01: APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Public Works Director. The Public Works
Director shall be appointed as provided in Section 03-02-01 of this Chapter.
The Public Works Director works under the broad policy guidance and direction
of the Mayor. (Ord. 3408, 3-21-2022)
03-22-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Required Skills, Knowledge and Abilities:
      A.   Good administrative, supervisory, communication and problem-solving
skills are required.
      B.   Knowledge of:
         1.   Generally-accepted engineering and construction practices;
         2.   Accounting and budgeting practices;
         3.   Equipment specifications and maintenance requirements; and
         4.   Construction and property surveying techniques.
      C.   Knowledge of City Codes and Ordinances.
      D.   Ability to deal with suppliers, contractors and the general public
and administer large-scale public works contracts.
   (2)   Acceptable Education and Experience: The Public Works Director shall
have a Bachelor of Science degree in engineering and at least six (6) years of
managerial experience in municipal public works or related field and experience
in property and construction surveying or an equivalent combination in
education and experience.
   (3)   Necessary Special Requirements: The Public Works Director shall have
and maintain a valid Idaho driver's license and shall be a licensed Civil
Engineer with the State of Idaho. (Ord. 3408, 3-21-2022)
03-22-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   General Statement of Duties: The Public Works Director is responsible
for management of all of the public works functions of the City.
   (2)   Supervision Exercised: He/she supervises a large number of
departmental personnel either directly or through subordinate supervisors.
   (3)   Illustrative Examples of Duties:
      A.   Overall supervision of the activities of the Sewer Department,
Street Department, Building Department, Airport Department, and Water
Department.
      B.   Prepares the annual budget for appropriate departments under the
supervision of the Public Works Director.
      C.   Advises the Mayor and City Council on a wide range of City-related
topics such as contracts, purchasing, personnel, engineering and developmental
impacts to City facilities or services.
      D.   Reviews subdivisions and proposed public facilities and services as
needed.
      E.   Supervises preparation and approval of Public Works Department
equipment specifications.
      F.   Coordinates the work of consultants when hired by the City to
prepare specialty reports or design specifications.
      G.   Assists in developing capital improvement schedules for all
departments of the City.
      H.   Serves as member of Grievance Review Board.
      I.   Prepares long-term facility improvement plans for Public Works
Department.
      J.   Serves as chair of the Caldwell Traffic Commission.
(Ord. 3408, 3-21-2022; amd. Ord. 3585, 3-19-2024)
ARTICLE 23
PLANNING AND ZONING DIRECTOR
SECTION:
03-23-01: Appointment
03-23-03: Qualifications And Job Requirements
03-23-05: Powers And Duties
03-23-07: Education And Experience
03-23-01: APPOINTMENT:
   There is hereby created the position of planning and zoning director. The
planning and zoning director shall be appointed as provided in section
03-03-01 of this chapter. The planning and zoning director works under the
broad policy guidance and direction of the mayor. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
03-23-03: QUALIFICATIONS AND JOB REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Required skills, knowledge and abilities:
      A.   Good oral and written communication skills; public speaking
techniques; budget preparation and control; and interpersonal skills using
tact, patience and courtesy.
      B.   Knowledge of current planning and zoning development laws;
principles and practices of administration, supervision and training; laws,
rules and regulations related to assigned activities; and technical aspects of
community development, economic development, historic preservation and planning
and zoning.
      C.   Ability to plan, organize, coordinate and direct the city's
community development program; coordinate and assure proper implementation and
enforcement of planning and zoning codes; train, assign, supervise and evaluate
the performance of assigned personnel; prepare and deliver oral presentations;
maintain records and prepare reports; prioritize and schedule work; interpret,
apply and explain rules, regulations, policies and procedures; and work
independently with little direction. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
03-23-05: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (1)   General statement of duties: The planning and zoning director plans,
organizes, coordinates and directs the city's planning and zoning and community
development programs; coordinates with the building official, city engineer,
public works director and the fire chief; prepares and develops preliminary
annual budgets and monitors and controls expenditures; develops and reviews
grants and special project applications; communicates with developers and
contractors related to proposed projects; develops, presents and implements
training and educational materials and programs for members of the planning and
zoning commission, city council, community groups, citizens and city staff;
reviews staff reports for consistency and compliance with city and department
policies and sound management; develops and recommends strategies and policies
for growth management and land use; reviews and recommends development of city
codes to regulate development; develops, submits and explains policy
recommendations; coordinates and discusses long range plans with other public
jurisdictions. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
03-23-07: EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE:
   Any combination equivalent to: Bachelor's degree in urban planning, public
administration or related field and five (5) years' increasingly responsible
experience in community development, urban planning, and economic development,
or
Master's degree and/or certification by the American Institute Of Certified
Planners preferred. (Ord. 2871, 3-7-2011)
